The Flying Squid is a {@item The Flying Squid|CallfromtheDeep|sailing ship} powered by a {@creature water elemental} which can be summoned by Sultan Klaptikos and bound to a gyroscopic adamantine prison in the hold. Successfully binding the elemental requires a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check which one of the characters can attempt after Klaptikos summons the elemental using the {@spell conjure elemental} spell. The ship is twice as fast as others of its ilk and only requires a crew of five.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: Characters gain levels in this chapter by completing the goals summarised below:

items: Characters who defend one of the Sword Coast cities advance to 6th level.
For each additional city defended, the characters may gain an additional level.
Characters who undertake additional quests have the chance to gain character levels at your discretion, advance one level per two quests as a rough guide.

entries.name: Chapter 3: Scouring the Seas
entries: A perilous coastline serves as the backdrop for this story. It transpires that the entirety of the Sword Coast and the Island Kingdoms are beset by pirates, the Kraken Society, with the mind flayers manipulating both. This chapter describes this setting, beginning with an overview of the Island Kingdoms and some of its key inhabitants, then presenting descriptions of specific locations. The chapter concludes with the characters discovering Sea King Tentrix's lair, a ship graveyard called Driftwood Docks in the Nelanther Isles.

Until the characters find a more expeditious means of transportation, they will be doing a lot of overland and overseas travel. {@book Chapter 5|dmg|5|Wilderness} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} provides advice and tools to help make wilderness travel fun for you and the players, as well as rules for foraging and becoming lost. You can use the travel-montage approach or the hour-by-hour approach, or you can experiment with both to see which approach works best for you. That chapter also includes a table to randomly determine the weather and a table of random urban encounters (useful when the adventurers arrive at a city).

entries.name: Folk of the Sword Coast
entries: West of the Sword Coast lies the Sea of Swords and beyond that the Trackless Sea, a vast expanse separating Faerûn from whatever lies to the far west. Between the shore and the unknown are a number of islands, some large and others so small they lack names of their own. These island nations make trade and war with Faerûn and one another just like any mainland nation.

Close to Faerûn are the Whalebones and Ruathym, ancient homes of the ancestors of the Illuskan people, and the Moonshaes where many of those same people now share the islands with the Ffolk and an elf offshoot known as the Llewyr. The free port of Mintarn lies nearby, a neutral site for meetings between enemies and a recruitment spot that offers abundant jobs for sailors. Despite its size, the tiny island of Orlumbor, with its treacherous harbour and its skilled, in-demand shipwrights, is an independent and influential nation unto itself. In the seas to the south, pirates of many races and predilections sail from the Nelanther Isles, preying on trade running north and south along the coast. Further to the north are the islands of Gundarlun, The Purple Rocks, and Tuern. Gundarlun is the only island member of the Lords' Alliance and boasts a powerful navy called the Kingsfleet which is busy defending the coast from pirates. Tuern is a violent place of tribal warfare and raiding, like many other Northlander isles. The Purple Rocks, a gathering of small islands ruled by native kings, pays homage to the kraken Slarkrethel. Their lives are defined by their worship of King of the Trackless Depths.

entries.name: Civilised Folk
entries: Humans are the most widespread of the civilised races, but no unified human nation exists on the Sword Coast, only individual cities, towns, villages, fiefdoms, farmsteads, fortresses, and outposts connected to one another by long, mostly unprotected rivers and roads. Human settlements rely on various industries for survival including fishing, mining, and farming. Coastal cities are home to human traders, shipbuilders, and artisans.

Although each city of the Sword Coast enjoys and maintains its independence, all these communities are at risk of being overrun by the monstrous threats that live outside their walls. Fear of the wilderness and its many terrors led to the formation of the Lords' Alliance, a loose confederacy of human-dominated settlements built on mutually beneficial trade agreements and a willingness to seek out and destroy threats to civilization. Members of the Lords' Alliance include the cities of Waterdeep, Neverwinter, Baldur's Gate, and the island of Gundbarg.

Within the settlements of the Sword Coast one can find humans, dwarves, elves, and other civilised races commingling more or less peacefully. Waterdeep, in particular, is a melting pot of races from all over Faerûn. Outside of these communities, however, people have much less tolerance for other races, as folk tend to feel safer among their own kind. Small towns and villages dominated by humans tend to have few, if any, non-humans, with most dwarves, elves, and halflings preferring to live in their own settlements, far from human-claimed lands. In generations past, most human settlers of the Island Kingdoms were fair-haired and light-skinned. Since then, the riches and promise of the islands have attracted folk from other regions, and several generations of cultural mingling has given the humans of Faerûn much greater diversity in their appearance (see "{@footnote {@race human|phb|Human Names and Ethnicities}|See the {@i Info} tab of the {@race human} race.}" in chapter 2 of the {@i Player's Handbook}).

entries.name: Northlanders
entries: The terms Northlander, Norls, Northfolk, and Northmen are interchangeable. They refer to one of several tall, fairhaired, seagoing peoples that ply the cold northern waters and dwell on the islands of the west including Tuern, Gundarlun, Ruathym, the Purple Rocks, and the Korinn Archipelago. Northfolk ancestors built small villages along the Sword Coast that have since become cities, including fabled Illusk (now Luskan), Eigersstor (now Neverwinter), and Nimoar's Hold (now Waterdeep). These early Northlanders farmed the rocky coastlines, fished coastal waters, and hunted seals and whales on the open sea.

Although Northlanders are often called barbarians, not all of them fit this description. Along the Sword Coast, some tribes have become fairly civilised, primarily due to the growth of the coastal cities and the increasing influence of outsiders. These people farm, fish, and mine their rugged lands, then shrewdly trade their goods with foreign buyers. Many once-feared tribes have become merchants whose bartering skills are equal to or better than the warlike talents of their ancestors, such that many a Northlander merchant earns more booty than their raiding neighbours. In many cases, however, the Northlanders of the Island Kingdoms still uphold the raiding and reaving culture of their past. Longships filled with berserkers loyal to one king set out over the waves to find new islands to plunder. Those who return with the finest goods and the biggest scars tend to become the next kings.

entries.name: Ffolk
entries: The Ffolk of the Moonshae Isles are descended from Tethyrian settlers who came to the islands a thousand years ago. The Ffolk have a deep respect for nature and are primarily farmers, worshiping the goddess they call the Earthmother and keeping to old druidic ways. Ffolk shipwrights are well regarded, having proven their ability to build sturdy ships that are capable of weathering the tumultuous seas around their home. The leader of the Ffolk is High King Derid Kendrick, who rules from the fortress of Caer Callidyr on Alaron. Despite their official ruler, the Ffolk are not the kind to be bound by society, and the druids of the woods and mountains pay little heed to the High King's court.

entries.name: Orcs and Half-Orcs
entries: The history of the North is replete with tales of orc hordes spilling out of the mountains to attack the mines, ranches, farmsteads, and settlements of other folk. When a particularly strong orc chieftain unites multiple tribes under one banner, the resulting horde typically rampages across the land, laying waste to strongholds and slaughtering other creatures in its path. Civilised communities form their own coalitions to combat rampaging orcs, with mixed results.

Not all orc chieftains are bent on destruction: King Obould Many-Arrows forged a tenuous alliance with his dwarf neighbours and helped maintain peace in the Silver Marches during his tumultuous reign. Some of the Many-Arrows orcs invaded Neverwinter during its time of troubles and still reside in the Tower District today. Half-orcs in the North are often burdened with the evil reputation of their orc cousins. It takes a half-orc of great character to step out of the shadow of evil and live as an equal among the civilised races.

entries.name: Shield Dwarves
entries: Shield dwarves (also known as mountain dwarves) have a number of strongholds along the Sword Coast including Ironmaster, Thornhold, and Gauntlgrym. Shield dwarves can also be found in smaller communities in the Island Kingdoms such as the Ironstar dwarves of Mintarn, and scattered clans in the Moonshae Isles. Few non-dwarves live in these bastions of dwarvenkind. Outside their walls, clans of shield dwarves are spread thinly throughout the Sword Coast, to the extent that it's hard to find a settlement that doesn't include at least a handful of dwarven residents.

entries.name: Elves
entries: Sun elves and moon elves, like dwarves, live among humans in settlements throughout the Sword Coast. The elven kingdoms of old are distant memories even to elves, and only a few ancient ruins and relics of these kingdoms survive. Dangerous and xenophobic wood elves are known to haunt certain forests along the Sword Coast. Few elves live out in the Island Kingdoms, save for the Llewyrr elves of the Moonshaes. They hail from the kingdom of Synnoria on the isle of Gwynneth. The Llewyrr are a mix of wood and moon elves, descended perhaps from a fleet on their way to Evermeet. They are often vegetarian and act as wardens over the animals of Myrloch Vale. The elves here mix freely with dwarves and humans so long as they are respectful of the wildlife.

entries.name: Halflings
entries: Small populations of lightfoot halflings can be found in most human-dominated settlements of the Sword Coast. Scattered throughout the fertile valleys of the North are small clusters of strongheart halfling homesteads, some of which spread into the lands of the Sword Coast. Halfling homesteads tend to be off the beaten path and well hidden, minimising the halflings' contact with bandits, barbarians, and marauding monsters. It's not unusual to see a quaint hamlet of halfling homesteads nestled in a grassy ravine or along the shore of a river. There are no large halfling communities in the Island Kingdoms, but families of more adventurous small-folk have emigrated overseas for a shot at a new life.

entries.name: Random Encounters
entries: While the characters are moving throughout the Sword Coast and Island Kingdoms they are likely to encounter wandering monsters. You should use the information in {@adventure Appendix A: Random Encounters|CallfromtheDeep|11} to help you manage the characters travel.

entries.name: Locations in the Island Kingdoms & Sword Coast
entries: The locations described in this section appear on the {@adventure Sword Coast map|CallfromtheDeep|0|Sword Coast Map} in this chapter. Additional information on several of these places can be found in the {@book Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide|scag}. Not depicted on the map are scores of tiny hamlets on the Sword Coast and dozens of tiny, unnamed islands scattered throughout the Island Kingdoms. These places are too small to be of consequence. Even so, adventurers traveling along a road or a trail might come across a tiny settlement consisting of a handful of homesteads built around an inn or tavern where locals gather. (If you need a tavern name, use the {@table Random Buildings; Tavern name Generator|dmg|Tavern Name Generator} table in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.)

Some location entries include a suggested encounter that occurs when the characters first arrive or shortly thereafter. You can ignore the encounter and create your own activity based on the information given in a location's description; for example, the "{@area Alaron|alaron|x}" section mentions evil fey creatures in the Dernal Forest, which might make for a fun encounter of your own creation. For the most part, the suggested encounters push the main narrative of Call from the Deep, helping you to keep your players interested in the campaign while they explore Faerûn.

entries.name: Sidebar: Water Pressure
entries: Some locations beneath the ocean are so deep that water pressure becomes a problem. Creatures and vehicles at a depth of 3,000 feet or lower take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage per minute from water pressure unless they are adapted or built to withstand this environment. Storm giants, whales, sharks, crustaceans, and aquatic invertebrates are immune to water pressure at this depth, as are vehicles with a damage threshold of 10 or higher.

Other creatures might be immune to the effect of water pressure at your discretion. Typically, a magic item that gives its wearer the ability to breathe water also protects it from deep-sea pressures.

entries.name: Alaron
entries: {@note More coming soon!}

data.name: Chapter 4: Pirate Kings & Kraken Priests
entries: {@note Coming soon!}

entries.name: Chapter 5: Ascarle
entries: The information the characters have gathered over the course of this adventure should lead them to the sunken city of Ascarle, not far from Purple Rocks. It is here that the powerful kraken Slarkrethel makes its home, and oversees the actions of the Kraken Society. Unknown to most, the kraken has been corrupted by the presence of Zellix'Phor, an elder brain from the Astral Plane whose nautiloid crash-landed on the island of Gundarlun at the start of this adventure. The mind flayer attendants of Zellix'Phor have altered Ascarle to their own needs, and to ensure that Zellix'Phor is protected.

Provided they keep their wits about them, the characters have the chance to destroy the elder brain, its mind flayer attendants, and perhaps even Slarkrethel the kraken. In order to be in with a chance, the characters must solve the puzzle of the abjuration brains (see {@adventure later in this chapter|CallfromtheDeep|9|Abjuration Brains}).

entries.name: Kraken & Elder Brain
entries: Slarkrethel's personality and psyche has been subdued by Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}. Zellix'Phor has been grafted into Slarkrethel's skull, and uses their psionic abilities to manipulate the kraken to their will. {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} is a {@creature kraken} with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: Slarkrethel has a challenge rating of 25 (75,000 XP).
It casts {@spell foresight} on itself before it attacks.

entries: It gains the Legendary Resistance and Spellcasting features described below.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Slarkrethel fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: Slarkrethel is a 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 22; {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following wizard spells prepared:

items: 1st level (4 slots): {@spell comprehend languages}, {@spell detect magic}, {@spell identify}, {@spell sleep}
2nd level (3 slots): {@spell blindness/deafness}, {@spell detect thoughts}, {@spell suggestion}
3rd level (3 slots): {@spell fly}, {@spell nondetection}, {@spell sending}
4th level (3 slots): {@spell arcane eye}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell locate creature}
5th level (3 slots): {@spell cloudkill}, {@spell scrying}, {@spell telekinesis}
6th level (2 slots): {@spell chain lightning}, {@spell flesh to stone}, {@spell mass suggestion}
7th level (2 slots): {@spell delayed blast fireball}, {@spell sequester}, {@spell teleport}
8th level (1 slot): {@spell control weather}, {@spell feeblemind}
9th level (1 slot): {@spell foresight}, {@spell power word kill}

entries: Zellix'Phor is in full control of Slarkrethel and can use the kraken's actions in place of its own. It can uses the kraken's speed and features, including spellcasting. Although the elder brain maintains its own features and actions, it cannot use its Tentacles while grafted into Slarkrethel.

Characters can choose to attack either the elder brain or the kraken, but the elder brain is protected (see "{@adventure Abjuration Brains|CallfromtheDeep|9|Abjuration Brains}"). This protection is obvious to the characters, who see magical auras surrounding Zellix'Phor.

Zellix'Phor wants to prevent intruders from entering its lair and, of course, wants to avoid dying. There are several 15-foot radius holes throughout Ascarle which lead into the dungeons, allowing the kraken and elder brain to manoeuvre in the dungeon and attack characters.

items.name: If Slarkrethel is about to be killed:
items.entry: Zellix'Phor uses {@spell teleport} to transport itself to {@area 70|70}, where its protective dome should keep it from harm.

items.name: If Zellix'Phor is about to be killed:
items.entry: it casts {@spell plane shift} to travel to the Fractured Hand on the Astral Plane (see "{@adventure Astral Retreat|CallfromtheDeep|9|Astral Retreat}"). The same is true for the various mind flayers that occupy the Dungeons.

entries.name: Ruins of Ascarle
entries: Eons ago, the city of Ascarle was built by moon elves on the northern coast of what came to be known as Trisk of Purple Rocks. They built the city from coral and crystal as they venerated {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} above all other deities. For centuries the elves lived in peace, cultivating unique architecture and art using the materials the ocean provided.

Unfortunately, peace could not last forever. Word of the rich city spread to the drow inhabiting the Underdark, who saw the chance to strike at an unsuspecting elven city and claim its treasures. Motivated by the bitter hatred of {@deity Lolth|Drow|mtf}, the drow sacked the city, killing many elves and routing the rest. The drow desecrated many of the shrines dedicated to {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}, but were kept from entering his most holy temple in the subterranean layer of the city by flooding the chambers with seawater. After spending less than a decade in their captured city, the drow returned to the Underdark.

Over the next century, the ruins of Ascarle were claimed by the Northern ice, which fractured the earth beneath the city, dragging it into the ocean as the glacier melted. Not long after, Slarkrethel discovered this new addition to his underwater realm and claimed it as his own. Since then, Slarkrethel has laired in Ascarle, appointing various evil wardens as Regent to guard the city. The most recent Regent was a rogue illithid named Vestress, who came to power in the 13th century DR.

In the Year of Maidens 1361 DR, the city was assaulted by the drow Lireal Baenre who fatally wounded Vestress and freed the captives from the city. Vestress was interred by the new Regent of Ascarle, an elven queen turned deathlock by Slarkrethel named Shava the Damned.

Within the past year, a major power shift has occurred. Slarkrethel has been dominated by Zellix'Phor, who was grafted into the kraken's skull. Zellix'Phor's illithid colony has taken up host in Ascarle, gaining command over the kraken's followers.

entries.name: Ruin Areas
entries: The ruins of Ascarle spread for miles and have a distinctly elven feel. Little is left of the ancient city, but a few pieces of architecture have defied the ravages of time and tide. Much of the ground is covered by vast forests of seaweed, huge boulders, and ruined walls. The central city is where the Krakenar and Slarkrethel spend most of their time.

entries.name: A. Hidden Entrance
entries: This building is covered with seaweed and is unguarded. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the building beneath. Entering the ruined chamber requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check to slip through the destroyed door, or through a crack in the wall. The stairs lead to {@area 1|1} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: B. Northern Entrance
entries: Slarkrethel and Zellix'Phor are here when characters first arrive. The hole in the ocean floor leads to {@area 21|21}.

entries.name: C. Krakenar Entrance
entries: Agents of the Krakenar are permitted to use this entrance to the lair. It is guarded by a triton {@creature champion|vgm} thrall, two {@creature merrow}, and four {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The stairs lead to {@area 15|15} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If the characters failed to rescue Ramazith Flamesinger in Baldur's Gate, there are an additional four {@creature merrow} guarding this entrance.

entries.name: D. Cave-In Entrance
entries: This entrance is inside a crumbling stone building that is covered with boulders. Entering the ruined chamber requires a successful DC 20 Strength check to remove the cave-in or break down a section of wall. The stairs lead to {@area 30|30} of the Dungeons of Ascarle.

entries.name: E. Western Entrance
entries: This entrance is guarded by six {@creature merrow}. It leads to {@area 32|32} of the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 20-foot drop.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If the characters failed to rescue Ramazith Flamesinger in Baldur's Gate, there are an additional four {@creature merrow} guarding this entrance.

entries.name: F. Seaweed Entrance
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice an entrance in the midst of the kelp forest. If their score is 20 or higher, the character notices two {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) guarding the entrance. The sea lions attack any non-Krakenar. The hole leads to {@area 40|40} of the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 30-foot drop.

entries.name: G. Southern Entrance
entries: This entrance is guarded by two merfolk {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests} and a {@creature sahuagin baron}. It leads behind {@area 42|42} to the Dungeons of Ascarle, down a 40-foot drop.

entries.name: Baldur's Gate
entries: If characters failed to rescue Ramazith Flamesinger in Baldur's Gate, there are an additional four {@creature merrow} gaurding this entrance.

entries.name: Dungeons of Ascarle
entries: The Dungeons of Ascarle are a mixture of moon elf, drow, Krakenar, and illithid architecture. Parts have remained unchanged for centuries while others are recently altered.

entries.name: Abjuration Brains
entries: Hidden throughout the dungeon are four brains of murdered spellcasters. Each brain is concentrating on an abjuration spell, and has been preserved in a jar which keeps the brain alive and enhances them, allowing them to maintain concentration on the spell until destroyed or the spell ends. The jars are clearly related to mind flayers due to their tentacle design and strange materials.

Each jar is hidden in its own area, and in its own way. Dealing damage to a jar, the brain within, or casting {@spell dispel magic} on the jar or brain ends the spell. Each brain is concentrating on a different spell:

items: {@area 24|24|u}. {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour}
{@area 37|37|u}. {@spell death ward}
{@area 78|78|u}. {@spell mind blank}
{@area 87|87|u}. {@spell globe of invulnerability}

entries: Various clues as to the meaning and location of the brains are scattered through the dungeon, but you can include other clues in the following ways:

items: Overheard conversations between Krakenar or mind flayer thralls.
Magical interrogation methods, such as {@spell zone of truth}, on the mind flayers.
Strange diagrams and scrawled notes in {@language Qualith|vgm} about the jars.

entries.name: Events in Ascarle
entries: Should the dungeon crawl become monotonous, use the following events to breathe new life into the adventure.

entries.name: Githyanki Attack
entries: A group of three {@creature githyanki warrior|mm|githyanki warriors} and Sarth Tra'ados ({@creature githyanki knight}) appear in Ascarle in their {@i astral skiff}. Characters might have met the githyanki in Neverwinter, where they assaulted the Cloak Tower. If they have been defeated, use three {@creature githyanki knight|mm|githyanki knights} each riding a {@creature young red dragon} from Flame Fault on Tuern. The githyanki try locate and destroy Zellix'Phor, potentially making them allies to the characters, though their fight first, questions later tactics might not align with those of the party.

entries.name: Krakenar Reinforcements
entries: If characters didn't kill all The Elders of Purple Rocks, the remaining {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests} take to the dungeon in search of the characters. They could be accompanied by a {@creature shoggoth|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) to help them search. You can use the kraken priests to introduce more eldritch horror to Ascarle, and could even implement the {@variantrule sanity scores|CallfromtheDeep|Sanity score} introduced in chapter 4 to up the level of threat they pose.

entries.name: Thunder & Lightning
entries: Two {@creature giff|mtf} mercenaries named Thunder and Lightning burst into the dungeon in an explosion of {@item smokepowder|wdh} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}). They are accompanied by a {@creature monodrone} dressed as a pirate, with an eyepatch and oversized tricorn hat. The giff are smokepowder obsessed and try to solve any problem before them through the use of the volatile substance. They arrived here after exploring a peculiar metal structure on a stone hand floating through the Astral Plane (see "{@adventure Astral Retreat|CallfromtheDeep|9|Astral Retreat}").

entries.name: Triton Thralls
entries: Six triton {@creature veteran} thralls on a giant manta ray (use the {@creature killer whale} statistics) are dispatched by the mind flayers in search of the characters. The manta ray is Large, and can only move through spacious areas of the dungeon, making use of the holes in the ceiling to track the characters.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/CallfromtheDeep/map/Ascarle (Player).jpg}.}

entries.name: General Features: Dungeons of Ascarle
entries: The following features are common throughout the dungeon. Additional Features sidebars are presented at the start of each relevant section:

entries.name: Seaweed
entries: Areas on the map marked with seaweed are overgrown with bladderwrack and eelgrass. Medium and smaller creatures can hide in the vegetation, as can Large creatures provided they drop {@condition prone}. A creature lying {@condition prone} in the seaweed has half cover. Any area occupied by the seaweed is considered difficult terrain.

entries.name: Water
entries: Much of the dungeon is submerged. Creatures that cannot breathe water must hold their breath. {@book Underwater combat|phb|9|underwater combat} rules apply. Where the water meets air, it is held back by arcane runes etched into the surrounding stone. A successful casting of {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20) causes water to start leaking through. The rest of the dungeon begins filling at a rate of 1 foot per minute.

entries.name: 1–16 Desecrated Catacombs
entries: The desecrated catacombs are eons old moon elf crypts, desecrated and partially destroyed during a drow invasion. Now, the catacombs are home to Shava the Damned, an undead elven Queen loyal to Slarkrethel.

This section of the dungeon has been submerged for centuries. The walls, floors, and ceilings are covered with algae and shellfish which have destroyed much of the original architecture. Seaweed has overtaken some chambers, making them superb monster lairs.

entries.name: Additional Features: Desecrated Catacombs
entries: The following features are common throughout the desecrated catacombs:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Most of the stone architecture of the catacombs is covered with a thick layer of algae and shellfish. Unless noted otherwise, ceilings are 10 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: The catacombs are unlit except where noted otherwise. Creatures rely on their {@sense darkvision} to see.
Ahead is a small chamber whose walls are covered with algae.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The stairs beyond this chamber lead to {@area A|a} in the Ruins of Ascarle.

entries.name: Eastern Doorway
entries: The door leading to this chamber on the eastern wall is concealed by the algae growing over it. The doorway can be discovered with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check.

entries.name: Divination
entries: Slarkrethel has a permanent {@spell arcane eye} and {@spell alarm} spells in this room. If the alarm is triggered, Slarkrethel uses the {@spell arcane eye} to discern what creatures have entered, commanding Shava to send creatures from {@area 15|15} to investigate.
The seaweed in this room wafts gently in the underwater currents. Piercing through the western wall and floor is a deep fissure.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Hidden in the seaweed near the fissure is a {@creature vodyanoi|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 11 or higher are not surprised by the lumbering crustacean when it attacks.

entries.name: Fissure
entries: The fissure is 30 feet deep and connects areas 2, {@area 14|14|x} and {@area 22|22|x}.
This room is filled with rotting furniture of coral.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check while searching through the debris discover a {@item piwafwi (cloak of elvenkind)|oota|piwafwi} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) left by the drow.
Two net-covered pits filled with crabs and lobsters take up the majority of this room.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Each pit contains swarms of crustaceans (use {@creature swarm of quippers} statistics). They are being fed by four {@creature sahuagin}.

entries.name: Pits
entries: Each pit is a 10-foot square and covered by a net. Inside are crustaceans used as food by the sahuagin and merrow when human flesh is scarce.

A hulking, four-armed sahuagin blocks the entrance to this corridor. The creature wields a vicious-looking trident and net. Tattooed across its chest is the stylised giant squid of the Kraken Society.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature sahuagin baron} guards this corridor. It wields a {@item net|phb} and a {@item vicious trident}. The sahuagin can make a {@item net|phb} attack in place of a claw or trident attack. If combat breaks out here, it alerts Shava the Damned in {@area 6|6}. She uses the opportunity to join the fight or flee through the secret door in that room.

Seated atop a throne of crystal and coral is a crowned elven woman whose fetid skin peels from her frame, revealing the bones beneath. In one hand she twirls a rod that resembles two intertwined tentacles capped with a fish skull.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Seated on the throne is {@creature Shava the Damned|CallfromtheDeep}, a {@creature deathlock mastermind|mtf} whose patron (Great Old One) is Slarkrethel. She wields a {@item +3 Rod of the Pact Keeper||+3 rod of the pactkeeper}, and wears a {@item ring of evasion} and a {@item ring of swimming}. {@note (All included in the linked stat block.)} Shava tries to recruit characters into the Kraken Society, but fights back if attacked. She knows Slarkrethel has been changed by Zellix'Phor, but does not see this as cause for concern.
Shava knows the function and location of the abjuration brains, though she doesn't give up the information willingly.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as her equipment, Shava wears a moonstone skull ring (100 gp) and a necklace of black pears (5,000 gp).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the northern door, which can be opened with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Shava uses it to escape if necessary.

entries.name: 7. Shava's Hoard
entries: The door to this chamber is magically locked and trapped. An {@spell arcane lock} means the door can only be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check, or a Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. A creature that touches the door immediately runs out of breath, unless it can breathe underwater.
When characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:
This chamber contains a barnacle-encrusted pile of ancient coins and treasure. Though most appears tarnished, a few peices stand out from the rest.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The room contains a pile of ancient elven currency (2,300 gp if cleaned), twelve {@item moonstone|dmg|moonstones} (50 gp each), ten {@item pearl|dmg|pearls} (100 gp each), a {@item figurine of wondrous power, aquamarine dolphin|CallfromtheDeep|figurine of wondrous power: aquamarine dolphin} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}), a suit of {@item elven chain}, and a pair of {@item drow slippers of spider climbing|CallfromtheDeep}.
Great swathes of seaweed fill this chamber, slowly undulating with the rippling current.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: characters searching through the seaweed that succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discover a toppled plinth, not far from which is an immaculate {@item crystal skull|CallfromtheDeep}. The skull can be used to cast the {@spell speak with dead} spell once per day.

This gallery before you overlooks a smaller chamber. The ceiling is held up by gently spiralling pillars reminiscent of conch shells. In an alcove on the eastern wall is a statue of an elf which has been partially covered with tar.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This area and {@area 10|10} below it is guarded by two {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep|sahuagin raiders} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and a {@creature merfolk conjurer|CallfromtheDeep} {@note (the {@race merfolk|CallfromtheDeep} racial traits have been added to the base {@creature conjurer|vgm} stat block)}.

entries.name: Light
entries: This room is lit by a perpetual {@spell dancing lights} spell created by the merfolk.

entries.name: Statue
entries: The elven statue covered with tar. Chiselled into its chest is an enormous spider symbol. Stuck over the eyes are two {@item ruby|dmg|rubies} (5,000 gp each). Prying a ruby from a socket without damaging it requires an edged tool and a successful DC 15 Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check.
Removing or damaging a ruby summons a {@creature yochlol} in its true form next to the statue. Only one yochlol is summoned, even if an additional ruby is damaged or removed.

entries.name: Passage
entries: The north-east of this chamber has been damaged. Large creatures can squeeze through the space.

A broad staircase leads from this chamber deeper into the dungeon. The walls are covered by bas-reliefs depicting elves sretching their arms toward the sea. Although it is covered in parts by algae, the beauty of the sculpture is evident.

entries.name: Light
entries: This room is lit by a perpetual {@spell dancing lights} spell.

entries.name: Stairs
entries: The stairs lead down to {@area 71|71}.

entries.name: Gallery
entries: This room is overlooked by {@area 9|9}.
A narrow, natural passageway leads to a featureless cavern filled with blue-green seaweed.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Lurking in this room is a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) and three {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). They warn creatures about the enraged Qualnus ({@area see below|13|x}).
Save for a few clumps of seaweed and a pile of rocky debris, this cavern is empty.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Hidden in debris is a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The crab tries to surprise Small creatures.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Inside the crab's gut is a platinum chalice set with bloodstones (2,500 gp)—this is the chalice that Qualnus is searching for (see {@area 13|13}).

A long, natural cavern with smooth stone walls curiously claer of algae lies ahead. Suspended in bubbles which slowly float throughout a dozen goblets and chalices. Two large, sandy mounds break line of sight through the cavern. A strange muttering emanates from somewhere within.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Qualnus, an {@creature eye of the deep|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) loyal to Shava, lairs here. Shava pays the aberration for its service with its favoured treasure; cups.

Characters who can speak {@language Primordial|phb|Aquan} or {@language Deep Speech|phb} hear Qualnus lamenting the loss of its favoured chalice. Qualnus doesn't know that the chalice was eaten by the hulking crab in {@area 12|12}. Returning the chalice creates an ally of Qualnus, who helps the characters with anything they desire. Qualnnus attempts to flee if reduced to half its hit points or fewer.

entries.name: Sanctum
entries: Accessible only by a hole in the ceiling is Qualnus' Sanctum (area 13a). This area contains a sandy bed for Qualnus to sleep in and three beautifully crafted platinum goblets set with various stones (2,500 gp each).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Floating in bubbles throughout the chamber are twelve goblets (8,000 gp total).

Despite the anemones and algae which cover them, the hundreds of death masks lining the walls of these catacombs are obvious. Sprouting off at regular intervals are the crypts of eons-dead elves. Many of the decorative elements of the tombs have been defaced with etchings of spiders and webs.

entries.name: Desecrated Ground
entries: Thanks to the unholy actions of the drow, the crypts are considered {@hazard desecrated ground} (see chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Six lacedons ({@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls} with a swim speed of 30 feet) hide in the western crypts. They attack intruders.

entries.name: Royal Crypts
entries: The eastern crypts belong to high-ranking moon elves and contain stone coffins. Three have been broken open and emptied, the other three remain intact.

An intact coffin can be opened with a successful DC 13 Strength check. Inside each is the skeleton of an elf adorned with magically protected jewellery and armour (500 gp per coffin). A {@spell detect magic} magic spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic around the pieces. Breaking open a coffin releases a {@creature banshee} which immediately attacks>

entries.name: Warrior Crypts
entries: The smaller alcoves contain shattered remnants of coffins belonging to lower-ranking elves.

entries.name: Statue and Secret Door
entries: Occupying the westernmost alcove is a humanoid statue wielding a wand and rapier. Its head has been removed. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice the outline of a doorway behind the statue. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals the statue is standing on a pressure plate which keeps the door sealed.

Moving the statue requires a successful DC 16 Strength check. Any non-elf that moves the statue causes the {@creature banshee|mm|banshees} to emerge from the royal crypts and attack (see above), unless they have already been destroyed. If the statue's head is replaced and fixed (using a {@spell mending} spell or {@item mason's tools|phb}), it bows low and can be commanded to move instead of forced. The head is located in {@area 16|16}.

entries.name: Fissure
entries: The fissure is 30 feet deep and connects {@area areas 2|2|x}, {@area 14|14|x}, and {@area 22|22|x}.
At the base of the grand stairs is a pillared antechamber.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The stairs in this chamber lead to {@area C|c} in the Ruins of Ascarle.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This chamber is guarded by four {@creature merrow} and a {@creature sahuagin priestess}. If two of the merrow die, one merrow flees to {@area 6|6} to warn Shava of the intruders.

This chamber has been thoroughly defiled. Chiselled into the walls are huge spiders aurrounded by cobwebs. The floor is covered with debris including shattered statue parts, bent and tarnished candlesticks, and the remnants of leather-bound tomes. An alcove on the southern wall houses a small altar which has an enormous, black metal spider atop it.

entries.name: Debris
entries: The elf statue's head (see {@area 14|14}) is here.

entries.name: Stairs
entries: The stairs in this chamber lead to {@area 10|10}.

entries.name: Altar
entries: A successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check reveals this alter was a shrine to {@deity Sehanine Moonbow|Elven|mtf}. Atop it is a metal spider. A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check reveals this to be a symbol of Lolth.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hanging above the altar is a {@item moonbow|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix C|CallfromtheDeep|13}) protected by an {@spell invisibility} spell. Removing the debris and metal spider from this chapel causes the altar to emit dim moonlight, revealing the {@item moonbow|CallfromtheDeep}.

entries.name: 17–31 Undersea Shrine
entries: This chapel was dedicated to {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} when the moon elves built Ascarle. Their proximity to the coast meant Sashelas had a strong following. The moon elves managed to collapse the entrance to the shrine when the drow attacked, preventing them from desecrating the place. Since the rift opened in {@area areas 2|2|x}, {@area 14|14|x}, and {@area 22|22|x}, the minions of Slarkrethel have been able to make their way between the them, though they have taken fewer protective measures thanks to the cave-in above.

entries.name: Additional Features: Undersea Shrine
entries: The following features are common throughout the undersea shrine:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Most surfaces are made of stone blocks decorated with dolphin motifs and mosaics. Unless noted otherwise, ceilings are 10 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: The shrine is unlit except where noted otherwise. Creatures rely on their {@sense darkvision} to see.
Up ahead is a long, featureless corridor of smooth stone. At the far end is a stone kraken statuette.

entries.name: Kraken's Arms
entries: {@i Complex trap (level 11–16, dangerous threat)
This trap was designed by the Kraken Society to prevent intruders getting into this section of Slarkrethel's lair.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: This trap activates if a creature not wearing a Kraken Society symbol enters the corridor, and stays active while such a creature remains within.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: The trap acts on initiative count 20 and 10.

entries.name: Active Elements
entries: The Kraken's Arms includes grasping tentacles along the first 60 feet, acidic water throughout, and an idol of fear in its final 30 feet.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The tentacles attack each creature in the first 70 feet of the hallway with a {@hit 8} bonus to the attack roll. A target hit by the attack takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape DC 15).

items.name: Acidic Water (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the corridor must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

items.name: Idol of Fear (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the 30-foot-long area beyond the Grasping Tentacles must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes {@condition frightened} of the idol, and must immediately use its action to move its speed toward the tentacles. The {@condition frightened} creature can't move closer to the idol until it uses its action to make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw, ending the condition on itself on a success.

entries.name: Dynamic Elements
entries: The acid and idol become more dangeorus the longer the trap remains active.

items.name: Acid Increases.
items.entry: More acid is pumped into the corridor. After its turn, the Acidic Water damage increases by 5 ({@damage 1d10}), to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

items.name: Idol's Defence.
items.entry: Tampering with the Idol of Fear causes a psychic wave. Each successful check made to disable the idol causes a 30-foot cone of energy to blast from it. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Constant Elements
entries: The Grasping Tentacles and Idol of Fear affect each creature that ends its turn in the area affected by these elements.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the tentacles' area is targeted by an attack: {@hit 5} attack bonus, 5 ({@damage 1d10}) bludgeoning damage on a hit.

items.name: Idol of Fear.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn within 30 feet of the idol must make a saving throw against the Idol of Fear effect.

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: Each of the trap's active elements can be thwarted by particular countermeasures.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles.
items.entry: Characters can sever the tentacles, attempt to dispel them, or dodge them. The tentacles disappear if their attack bonus is reduced to {@hit -8}. Ways to reduce it are described below:

items.name: Dexterity (Acrobatics), DC 15.
items.entry: As an action, a creature that can see the tentacles can attempt a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. A successful check allows the character to dodge the tentacles' failing, imposing disadvantage on the tentacles' attacks against the creature while it isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

items.name: Attack.
items.entry: A creature in the area can {@action ready} an attack against one of the tentacles as it goes by. The tentacle gains advantage on its attack against the creature. The creature then attacks. Each tentalce has AC 15 and 15 hit points. Destroying a tentacle reduces the Grasping Tentalces attack bonus by 2.

items.name: Intelligence (Arcana) check, DC 15.
items.entry: Creatures can use their knowledge of magic to attempt to dispel the shadowy tentacles. A successful check reduces the Grasping Tentacles attack bonus by 2.

items.name: Acidic Water.
items.entry: Characters can attempt to neutralise the acid or to block the holes from which it leaks:

items.name: Neutralise.
items.entry: A creature can reset the Acid Water damage to 0 by casting {@spell purify food and drink} or similar magic.

items.name: Block the Holes.
items.entry: There are four sets of holes through which the acid is pumped. A creature can use an action to make a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, finding a set of holes on each success. A subsequent action can be used to plug the holes with shredded cloth. Once all four sets are plugged, the ACidic Waters damage cannot increase.

items.name: Idol of Fear
items.entry: The idol can be dispelled or destroyed:

items.name: Dispel.
items.entry: The idol can be dispelled with three successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) checks. Each check requires an action. A creature must be within 5 feet of the idol to attempt this check, and only one creature can work on this task at any one time. Alternatively, the idol can be disabled with three successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15) spells.

items.name: Destroy.
items.entry: The idol has AC 15, 50 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and resistance to all nonmagical damage.

entries: A hulking monstrosity, half-fish half-lion, coils around this chamber nosing at piles of discarded bones. The ceiling and pillars holding up the chamber up appear to be badly dmaged.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The {@creature sea lion|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) can be distracted by food, but only eats raw beasts and humanoids. If no suitable offering is made, it attacks whoever enters.

entries.name: Pillars and Ceiling
entries: The pillars in the chamber are almost destroyed. A creature that misses a melee attack roll within 5 feet of a pillar must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature hits the pillar, destroying it.

If all four pillars are destroyed the ceiling caves in. Each creature in the chamber must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. A creature that fails the save is buried under stone and sand. While buried, the creature is {@condition prone} and {@condition blinded}. It can't breathe and has total cover against attacks and other effects.

A creature that starts its turn buried takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage. A burrowing creature can move through the collapsed area at its burrowing speed, leaving no tunnel in its wake. A buried creature that doesn't have a burrowing speed can make a DC 15 Strength check on its turn. If the check succeeds, the creature can pull itself in any direction at a rate of 1 foot for every 5 feet of movement spent. A creature standing at either end of the collapsed area can use an action to pull a buried creature out of the area with a successful DC 15 Strength check.

Bursting through the floor of this room is a steam vent from which a stream of bubbles surge, heating the chamber. Around the vent's base is a circle of symbols. The walls are adorned with tapestries portraying the elemental planes.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There are two {@creature water elemental|mm|water elementals} in the area.

entries.name: Steam Vent
entries: Creatures that move directly above a vent for the first time on a turn, or that start their turn there, take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

entries.name: Conjuration Circle
entries: The circle gives elemental creatures advantage on attack rolls and saving throws, and any conjuration spells cast in the area last for twice their normal duration. Casting {@spell dispel magic} destroys the circle.

entries.name: Concealed Door
entries: Behind the southern tapestry is a door. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notice the tapestry flap as if moved by a current.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notice a bookshelf behind the eastern tapestry. It contains a {@item spellbook|phb} with the spells {@spell conjure elemental}, {@spell conjure minor elementals}, and {@spell planar binding}, and a jade scroll case (200 gp) containing three {@item spell scroll|dmg|spell scrolls}; {@spell arcane gate}, {@spell chain lightning}, and {@spell plane shift}.

Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice one book has clearly been used recently. It concerns the extension of spell concentration, even beyond death. Several pages have been torn out. This provides a clue to the presence of the abjuration brains.
Taking anything from the bookshelf causes three {@creature water elemental myrmidon|mtf|water elemental myrmidons} to emerge from the vent and attack.
There are two medium tapestries (150 gp each) and one large tapestry (250 gp). They are warded with abjuration magic which prevents them from degrading naturally.

entries.name: Waterdeep
entries: If characters failed to recover the {@item marid conch|CallfromtheDeep}, the {@creature marid} Sultan Klaptikos of the Great Wave is here fighting for the Kraken Society. He guards this chamber and those beyond with his life.

entries.name: 20. Armoury

entries: Empty weapon racks hang from the walls in this chamber.
This area is empty.

Darting around in this broad chamber are ephemeral, silver-coloured dolphins. Sprawling patches of seaweed sprout from beneath the craked mosaic floor whose original design is unrecognisable. High up in the ceiling is a ragged hole, through which filters a soft turquoise light.

entries.name: Ceiling & Light
entries: The ceiling of this chamber is 20 feet tall. The room is dimly lit (see below).

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The 15-foot radius hole in the ceiling leads to {@area B|b} of the Ruins of Ascarle.

entries.name: Dolphins
entries: Filling the chamber is a permanent {@spell dancing lights} spell which manifests as silver dolphins. They avoid being touched. If a creature touches one, they have {@spell polymorph} cast upon them (save DC 15) with the new form as a {@creature dolphin|vgm}. The spell lasts until dispelled.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Floating amongst the dolphins is an {@creature eidolon|mtf}; an amorphous spectre. The eidolon protects {@area 24|24} from desecration. The Krakenar have avoided its wrath by maintaining a shrine to {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}. The eidolon pursues anyone who takes items from the shrines in {@area 24|24}. Its sacred statue is in {@area 23|23}.

Although the eidolon is only a fractured version of its former self, it can still speak {@language Elvish} and uphold a conversation. Good roleplay or a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check calms the angry spirit.
A broad fissure slices this room in two. The damage caused by this has destroyed any evidence of the room's purpose.

entries.name: Fissure
entries: The fissure is 30 feet deep and connects {@area areas 2|2|x}, {@area 14|14|x}, and {@area 22|22|x}.
Looming above is a near-perfect rendition of an elven warrior in white marble. The statue is unerringly lifelike.

entries.name: Statue
entries: The elven warrior statue is a sacred statue which can be inhabited by the eidolon in {@area 21|21}.

Three white marble altars are placed on a raised dias on the northwestern wall. The altars are devoid of seaweed and algae, and have a panoply of paraphernalia pertaining to different deities atop them.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A secret door connects {@area 28|28} and 24. Creatures with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice the door. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check allows a creature to open the door by tracing a dolpin upon it.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Guarding the shrine is a {@creature giant shark}, two merfolk {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests}, and four {@creature sahuagin}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The total value of holy symbols and offerings on the altars is 3,000 gp. Characters who succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognise the symbols as belonging to Slarkrethel, {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}, and {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag}.

entries.name: Canopic Jar
entries: Atop the central shrine is a canopic jar containing a spellcaster's brain concentrating on {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour} (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains|x}").

entries.name: Mosaic
entries: The mosaic is the key to the puzzle in {@area 26|26}. Left to right, the animals are dolphin, orca, eel, squid.
A beautiful mosaic of coloured tiles covers the walls of this room. The craftmanship is remarkable. It depicts an underwater scene of dolphins, orcas, eels, and squid.

A deep pit fills this otherwise empty chamber. At the bottom of the pit are a handful of statuettes of different marine animals. Beyond the pit is a stone door covered with an engraving of a coral reef.

entries.name: Statuettes
entries: There are six statuettes at the bottom of the pit in this chamber: a dolpin, eel, orca, shark, squid, turtle.

Picking up a statuette causes a spectral duplicate of said creature to appear. The creatures have AC 15, 50 hit points, resistance to nonmagical damage, and one attack option: {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target, dealing 11 ({@damage 2d10}) force damage on a hit. If the statuette is dropped the duplicate disappears. If destroyed, the duplicate reforms in {@dice 1d4} rounds provided the statuette is still being held.

entries.name: Beyond the Door
entries: Behind the door is a small chamber containing four alcoves. Placing the dolphin, orca, eel, and squid statuettes in the alcoves, in that order, causes a secret door to appear. Until the statuettes are placed into the correct alcoves, the secret door cannot be discovered.
The statuettes disappear from the alcoves after 10 minutes, after which they reappear in the pit. During these 10 minutes, the {@trap Wrath of Undersea|CallfromtheDeep} trap is deactivated.

entries.name: Wrath of Undersea
entries: {@i Complex trap (level 11–16, deadly threat)
The wrath of Undersea is a deadly trap devised by the acolytes of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} to protect their holy treasures.

entries.name: Trigger
entries: This trap activates as soon as a creature not beraing a symbol of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} enters the room, and remains active while such a creature is in the room.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: The trap acts on initiative 20 and 10.

entries.name: Active Elements
entries: The trap fills the room with a whirlpool and other deadly effects.

items.name: Sleep Spell (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The trap casts the {@spell sleep} spell at 9th level (94 ({@dice 21d8}) hit points).

items.name: Whirlpool (Initiative 20).
items.entry: A whirlpool forms centred on the bottom of the pit. Each creature in the room must make a DC 20 Strength saving throw. On a failed saving throw, the creature takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and is pulled 30 feet toward the bottom of the pit. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} or pulled.

items.name: Seaweed Growth (Initiative 10).
items.entry: A 5-foot-thick mat of seaweed grows to cover the pit.

entries.name: Dynamic Element
entries: The longer the whirlpool lasts, the more lethal it becomes.

items.name: Increased Velocity.
items.entry: The damage from the Whirlpool element increases by 11 ({@damage 2d10}) each round after it activates, to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

entries.name: Countermeasures
entries: The trap can be thwarted in the following ways:

items.name: Whirlpool.
items.entry: Characters can use an action to brace themselves against the floor, wall, or ceiling. Doing so gives them advantage on the saving throw against the Whirlpool element until the start of their next turn.

items.name: Seaweed Mat.
items.entry: A 5-foot square section of the mat can be destroyed with either a successful DC 20 Strength check or by attacking it (AC 15, 15 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage).

items.name: Leave the Room
items.entry: The easiest way to deactivate the trap is to leave the room. Once the room is empty of triggering creatures, it deactivates.

entries.name: 27. Elven Treasure Vault

entries: A glittering hoard of wealth is piled high ahead. Immaculate suits of mithral armour hang from mannequins, masterpieces of painting and threadwork line the walls, and chests filled with magnificent jewllery overflow onto the marble floor.
This area is only accessible by solving the puzzle in {@area 26|26}.

entries.name: Protective Spells
entries: This area is protected by the {@spell hallow} spell with the Extradimensional Interference effect, and a permanent {@spell nondetection} spell.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The two chests each contain 35,000 gp of assorted jewellery and gemstones. There are four tapestries and two paintings (2,500 gp each). A {@item mithral breastplate}, {@item mithral chain mail|dmg}, and an {@item elven chain} hang from mannequins. The rack contains an {@item adamantine longsword|xge}, a {@item trident of warning}, and a {@item +2 rapier}. A small silver box with inlaid sapphires (1,500 gp) contains a {@item potion of flying}, a {@item potion of invisibility}, a {@item potion of speed}, and two {@item potion of supreme healing|dmg|potions of supreme healing}.
This rounded corridor is paved with azurite flagstones that glitter gently. A few rooms and alcoves branch off from it, and a large marble statue of an elf stands at one end.

entries.name: Statue & Secret Door
entries: The statue is of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf}, depicted as a fair elven man accompanied by a dolphin. He points his metal trident at a portion of the wall which is actually a secret door.

Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notice the door. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals that using the statue's trident to trace the frame opens the door.
If the trident leaves this area, it disappears in a cloud of bubbles and reappears in the statue's hand.

entries.name: Alcoves & Secret Door
entries: Recessed from the corridor in alcoves are bas-reliefs depicting elven royalty. One of them matches Shava the Damned. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice a skillfully disguised Qualith Door Lock built into the sculpture (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: 29. Storerooms

entries: These seaweed-filled chambers contain mouldering artifacts that time and the sea have rendered unrecognisable.
These areas only contain seaweed (see "{@area General Features: Dungeons of Ascarle|gfdoa|x}").

The broad staircase in this chamber leads down to a mosaic floor with glittering blue tiles forming a dolphin symbol. Raised high above the stairway are two plinths, each of which is capped with a hideous gargoyle.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The two gargoyles are kapoacinths ({@creature gargoyle|mm|gargoyles} with a 60-foot swim speed). They attack any intruders.

Characters who can speak {@language Primordial|phb|Aquan} or {@language primordial|phb|Terran} can convince the kapoacinths that they are Krakenar with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The stairs in this chamber lead to {@area D|d} in the Ruins of Ascarle.
Ahead is a cylindrical tunnel plated with iridescent metal.

entries.name: Trap
entries: Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice a pressure plate at the end of the corridor. Weight applied to these plates locks the doors and casts {@spell cloudkill} at 9th level throughout the corridor.

entries.name: Secret Doors
entries: The doors are unlocked Qualith Door Locks (see "{@area Additional Features: Illithid Lair|afil|x}").

entries.name: 32–41 Corrupted Caverns
entries: These natural caves once formed the majority of Slarkrethel's lair but were demolished when the illithids excavated the domed caverns to house their quarters.

The caverns and their inhabitants are warped and twisted beings whose contact with the Far Realm through Slarkrethel have preternaturally changed them. Worse still, the caves are now home to rejected mind flayer experiments. Occasionally, the devout of Purple Rocks come to venerate Slarkrethel and his spawn in these caves.

entries.name: Additional Features: Corrupted Caverns
entries: The following features are common throughout the corrupted caverns:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: The natural stone walls are rough and damp. Unless noted otherwise, ceilings are 20 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: The caverns are dimly lit by torches along the walls.

entries.name: Sanity
entries: If you want to make this area of the dungeon deadlier, consider using the optional {@variantrule sanity scores|CallfromtheDeep|Sanity} rules presented in chapter 4, "Sanity Scores".

Broad tunnels cut through the rock forming a circuit of subterranean walkways. The enormous cavern smells damp and ferrous, and the falling of droplets echoes throughout. Hunched figures lurch throughout the cave.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Eight humanoid {@creature gibbering mouther|mm|gibbering mouthers} lumber throughout the cavern. They ignore the warped ground.

entries.name: Warped Ground
entries: Squares on the map marked with swirls appear like regular stone but are actually 10-foot-deep pools of tar-like acid. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice the stone swirling slightly, indicating the corrupted nature.

A creature that steps on a marked square is treated as falling into {@hazard quicksand} (see chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). In addition, when a creature enters the marked square for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) acid damage.

entries.name: Ceiling & Ledge
entries: The ceiling is 50 feet high in this cavern. The ledge is 30 feet high.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The 15-foot-radius hole in the ceiling leads to {@area E|e} of the Ruins of Ascarle. The water is held back by arcane runes (see "{@area General Features: Dungeons of Ascarle|gfdoa|x}").

Separated from the rest of the caverns by rusted iron bars is an arched chamber from which hundreds of fang-like stalagmites hang. In the centre of the natural stone floor is a deep pit, and in a nearby hollow a greenstone altar splattered with some unnamable fluid. Atop it is a whalebone idol.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Both iron-barred doors are locked. The key is in {@area 34|34}. The doors can be opened with a successful DC 20 Strength check or a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The idol atop the altar depicts a hideous, crouched, tentacled monstrosity with folded, leathery wings that is at once reminiscent of a man, a dragon, and a giant squid. The idol is actually a {@creature graven image|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) that attacks any non-Rocklanders who enter the cavern.

entries.name: Pit
entries: In the bottom of the pit is a mutated, emaciated corpse that is too close to a human child for comfort. Each creature that sees the corpse must make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature gains a form of {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: On the altar are six {@item zircon|dmg|zircons} (50 gp each), a {@item potion of water breathing} in a brass ewer with a jade inlay (250 gp) and a {@item candle of invocation|dmg|chaotic evil candle of invocation}.
Behind a rickety wooden door is a dormitory with two mangy bunk beds and a wonky table.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two Rocklander {@creature cult fanatic|mm|cult fanatics} and a {@creature warlock of the great old one|vgm} one wearing a {@item robe of eyes} made from flesh are sat at the table hand in hand. Their veneration of Far Realm beings has sent them insane. Though they are not hostile, they might find colour green intensely offensive. Flaunting it causes them to attack, as does searching this area or stealing from {@area 33|33}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Under the pillow of one of the bunks is a key to {@area 33|33} and a book filled with symbols. The symbols can be made by the statues in {@area 41|41}. Next to each are scrawled notes ({@adventure appendix E|CallfromtheDeep|15|Cultist Statue Notes}). The book itself gives no direction to that area, nor how to use the statues.

entries.name: Ceiling
entries: This chamber is 10 feet tall.
Hundreds of stalagmites sprout from the floor, creating a vicious vista of stone spears.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature urophion|CallfromtheDeep|urophions} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) are hidden amongst the stalagmites.

entries.name: Stalagmites
entries: The number of stalagmites in this chamber makes it difficult terrain. Any creature that falls prone in the area takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) piercing damage. Larger stalagmites are shown on the map.

A deep pool of stagnant water fills this chamber. It reeks of rotting shellfish and is cloudy with a fibrous sediment. Every few secodns a drop falls from the ceiling, sending ripples across the surface of the pool.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature uchuulon|CallfromtheDeep|uchuulons} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep}) are hidden in the pool. They attempt to ambush the characters, but are noticed by those with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher when they are within 10 feet of the surface.

entries.name: Water
entries: The 30-foot-deep pool is filled with rotting detritus, restricting visibility to 10 feet. Any creature other than the uchuulons that falls in the pool must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition poisoned} for one hour. On a successful save, the creature is immune to the effect for 24 hours.
The floor of this submerged cavern sinks down tens of feet.

entries.name: Canopic Jar
entries: At the bottom of the pool is a canopic jar containing the spellcaster's brain concentrating on {@spell death ward} (see "{@area Abjuration Brains|abjuration brains|x}").

entries.name: Water
entries: The area is under 60 feet of water (see {@area 36|36}).

The walls of this cavern are covered in petroglyphs. The hideous, unspeakable forms portrayed in the ancient artwork are appalling to behold, and the acts of debauchery in which they are engaged makes the depictions all the worse.

entries.name: Petroglyphs
entries: Characters who succeed a DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check notice part of the petroglyphs is more modern. It depicts priests warding off strange aberrations with green fire—a clue for getting past the guardian in {@area 39|39}.

If a character fails the check, they must make a DC 18 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness|dmg|short-term form of madness}, or a {@table long-term madness|dmg|long-term form} if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A deep trench lines the edge of this natural cavern from which green fire belches sporadically. To either side of the doorway are unlit braziers mounted in brackets on the wall.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Guarding the entrance to {@area 40|40} is a {@creature star spawn hulk|mtf}. It attacks characters that attempt to enter {@area 40|40}. If the characters bear a brazier lit with green flame the creature cowers and lets them pass.

entries.name: Trench
entries: A 10-foot-deep trench skirts the perimeter. A creature that enters the trench for the first time on a turn, or starts its turn there, takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

Veins of midnight black minerals carve through the rock walls of this huge fane, giving it an unsettlingly visceral look. Two staircases lead up to a raised level above which is a broad fissure open to the ruins above. On this level, four braziers of green flame burn brightly, illuminating a haunting ritual sacrifice about to take place.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature cult fanatic|mm|cult fanatics} and two {@creature kraken priest|vgm|kraken priests} are engaged in the ritual. One priest pins down Balama Domine (NG female Turami human {@creature thug}) while the other concentrates on a ritual that transforms Balama into a {@creature star spawn mangler|mtf} at the end of the priest's second turn.
Characters can prevent the ritual by depriving the priests of their sight or ability to speak, breaking the caster's concentration, or casting {@spell counterspell} or {@spell dispel magic}.

entries.name: Trapped Stairs
entries: The stairs closest the door are trapped. Stepping on the top stair causes the staris to tilt, turning into a slide. Simultaneously, a 10-foot square pit filled with green fire opens at the bottom of the stairs. Any creature on the stairs when the trap is triggered must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or slide into the pit.
When a creature enters the pit for the first time on a turn, or starts its turn there, it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage.
Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 18 or higher notice the trap, and can avoid the top step.

entries.name: Ceiling & Levels
entries: The ceiling of this chamber is 50 feet tall. The platform is 20 feet tall.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: The 15-foot-radius hole in the ceiling leads to {@area F|f} in the Ruins of Ascarle.
This wide chamber is bordered by midnight black columns in stoas. In the centre are six identical green stone statues. The hideous forms vomit forth twisting beams of black energy.

entries.name: Statues
entries: Each statue can be rotated using an action. The beams continue until they hit a statue, wall, column, or creature. Overlapping beams has no additional effect.
A creature hit by the beam is targeted by a {@spell ray of enfeeblement} (DC 20). If a beam hits a pillar, a {@spell wall of fire} (DC 20) stretches between each pillar and wall on that side.

If a beam hits a statue it stops there. Different symbols can be made by the beams by rotating the statues. Each symbol causes a different effect (see {@adventure appendix E|CallfromtheDeep|15|Statue Symbols}):

items.name: Symbol A.
items.entry: A {@creature yuan-ti anathema|vgm} is summoned between the central pillars—it attacks randomly.

items.name: Symbol B.
items.entry: Both doors on the eastern wall unlock until the symbol changes.

items.name: Symbol C.
items.entry: Each creature in the room is subjected to the {@spell slow} spell (DC 20) until the symbol changes.

items.name: Symbol D.
items.entry: A {@creature doppelganger} of each creature appears in the room in a mirrored position (as if creating symmetry down the central line).

items.name: Symbol E.
items.entry: Each creature in the room is subjected to the {@spell haste} spell until the symbol changes.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The doors on the eastern wall are both locked, and can only be opened by making the required symbol. Attempting to open the doors before they are unlocked causes the following effects:

items.name: Left-Hand Door.
items.entry: A creature that opens the door sees a cavernous tunnel beyond, created by the {@spell silent image} spell (DC 20). A creature that steps through the door is teleported to {@area 67|67}, though the illusion responds as if they had walked through. Casting {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20) on the door ends both the illusion and teleportation magic.

items.name: Right-Hand Door.
items.entry: A creature that opens the door causes the floor on the corridor beyond to be targetted by a permanent {@spell spike growth} spell (DC 20). It can be removed by {@spell dispel magic} (DC 20).

entries.name: Ceiling & Levels
entries: The chamber is 30 feet tall. The levels by the door are 20 feet high.

entries.name: 42–59 Illithid Lair
entries: Sculpted from burnished star metal and bent glass, the lair of the illithid colony hideously alien. It was constructed by illithid thralls after the great domed caverns were created from the original caves. The inhabitants are the disciples of Zellix'Phor, a handful of newly created mind flayers, and the colony's thralls which serve them without question.

entries.name: Entrance/Exit
entries: Around the rear of the illithid lair is a 15-foot-radius hole which leads to {@area G|g} in the Ruins of Ascarle. The water is held back by arcane runes (see "{@area General Features: Dungeons of Ascarle|gfdoa|x}").

entries.name: Additional Features: Illithid Lair
entries: The following features are common throughout the lair:

entries.name: Ceilings, Floors, and Walls
entries: Each chamber is 10 feet tall. Most surfaces are made of burnished meteoric iron that is iridescent and cold to the touch.

entries.name: Gas Traps
entries: Several areas of the lair are trapped. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 20 or higher notice pressure plates on the floor.

Stepping on a pressure plate triggers the trap. All doors slam shut and lock as poisonous gas fills the room. Creatures in the room when the trap activates, and when a creature starts its turn in the room, muts make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The gas linger for 10 minutes, or until a door is opened.

entries.name: Light
entries: The entire lair is well lit by glowing crystals built into the walls, powered by generators in {@area 45|45}.

entries.name: Qualith Door Locks
entries: Mounted on both sides of the door to this chamber are plates of burnished metal embossed with a braille-like form of tactile writing known as {@language Qualith|vgm}. Mind flayers use their tentacles to read Qualith, which is composed in four-line stanzas indecipherable to other creatures. A creature that touches a Qualith inscription, however, can receive fragmentary insight into the multilayered thoughts contained within it. A non-illithid that wants to understand a Qualith inscription can make a DC 18 Intelligence check to interpret the inscription. A failed attempt results in a crushing headache and requires the creature to succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or develop a form of {@table short-term madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). A {@spell comprehend languages} spell provides an understanding of the text roughly equivalent to what a mind flayer would get from it.

Each door plate is imbued with psionic energy and functions like an {@spell arcane lock} spell. The Qualith inscription on the plate describes the genuflections a mind flayer must make with its tentacles to open the door. Other creatures with at least four tentacles can imitate these motions to bypass the lock, provided they can interpret the inscription. A creature must be within 5 feet of the door to open it in this way. Creatures without the requisite tentacles and knowledge must deal with the lock by more conventional means, such as a {@spell knock} spell. If magic is unavailable, a locked door can be opened with a successful DC 30 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.
Clever adventurers might discover that a decapitated mind flayer head, animated through an {@spell animate dead} spell, can be used to access the locks.
Unless held open, doors with Qualith door locks automatically close and lock moments after use.

entries.name: Restoration Pods
entries: Several chambers within the lair contain Restoration Pods. These pods are used to rest by the mind flayers. A creature can use an action to step into a pod and close it.
