data.name: Appendix D: Ships & Crew
entries: The following information should help you run a ship for your players, and includes example ships and crews to help manage random encounters at sea.

entries.name: Running a Ship
entries: {@note The following is a simplified version of the rules presented in {@adventure Ghosts of Saltmarsh|GoS|8}. You may wish to use those {@variantrule Ship Stat Blocks|GoS|rules} and their respective {@filter stat blocks|vehicles|source=GoS} instead.}

This adventure contains the potential for lots of naval combat. Because of this, you need to note the type of ship the characters are using, it's speed, required crew, AC, HP, and damage threshold. These statistics can be found in the "Ship Statistics" section.

When naval combat breaks out, have each vessel roll initiative separately from the rest of the characters. The ships have a bonus to initiative equal to the average bonus of the crew. For example, a ship crewed by mostly {@creature guard|mm|guards}, who have a {@dice 1d20+1|+1} to initiative, also has a {@dice 1d20+1|+1} to initiative.

A ship can take the following actions on its turn; {@action Attack}, {@action Dash}, or {@action Dodge}. When a ship takes the {@action Attack} action, assume that it uses all its weapons so long as there are enough crew to use them (remembering that some weapons take multiple action to use). Taking the {@action Dash} action allows a ship to move twice as fast as it normally would, but may require a successful Strength check at the DMs discretion. A ship that {@action Dodge|phb|Dodges} is assumed to be manoeuvred in such a way as to make it harder to hit.

At times, the ship may have to make ability checks or saving throws, for example, to avoid a collision with rocks or an enemy vessel, or perhaps to avoid rocks whilst {@action Dash|phb|Dashing}. Like initiative, refer to the average bonus of the crew.

Ships that are damaged can be repaired. Repairs to a damaged ship can be made while the vessel is berthed. Repairing 1 hit point of damage requires 1 day and costs 20 gp for materials and labour. Ships can also be upgraded (see the "Upgrades" section).

If you don't think your players will enjoy this, you can run their ship for them, or ignore these rules altogether, and simply run the naval battles in a narrative fashion, relying heavily on the characters actions.

entries.name: Ship Statistics
entries: Each ship presented belows is given a number of different statistics that tell you something about the ship's requirements or capabilities.

entries.name: Ship
entries: This tells you the type of ship you are looking at.

entries.name: Cost (gp)
entries: This tells you the cost to purchase or build such a ship in gold pieces.

entries.name: Speed (mph)
entries: This tells you the speed of the ship in miles per hour, most useful for travel over long distances out of combat. Remember that ships with sails cannot move without a wind, but can potential move for 24 hours a day if the crew rotate and the wind stays favourable.

entries.name: Speed (per turn)
entries: This tells you the how many feet a ship can move on its turn during combat.

entries.name: Crew
entries: A ship needs a crew of skilled hirelings to function. As per the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|5|Services|0}, one skilled hireling costs at least 2 gp per day. The minimum number of skilled hirelings needed to crew a ship depends on the type of vessel, as shown in the table. If the number of crew drops below this number, the ship cannot function at full capacity (not all weapons can be fired, the ship's speed is reduced by half etc.). The exact nature of the malfunction is determined by the DM. Should the number of crew fall below half this number, the ship cannot be used.

You can track the loyalty of individual crew members or the crew as a whole using the optional {@variantrule loyalty|dmg} rules in chapter 4 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}. If at least half the crew becomes disloyal during a voyage, the crew turns hostile and stages a mutiny. If the ship is berthed, disloyal crew members leave the ship and never return.

entries.name: Passengers
entries: The table indicates the number of Small and Medium passengers the ship can accommodate. A Large creature takes up 4 spaces. Most ships are not designed for Huge or larger creatures to board. Accommodations consist of shared hammocks in tight quarters. A ship outfitted with private accommodations can carry one-fifth as many passengers.
A passenger is usually expected to pay 5 sp per day for a hammock, but prices can vary from ship to ship. A small private cabin usually costs 2 gp per day.

entries.name: Cargo (Tons)
entries: The {@table Ship Statistics|CallfromtheDeep|table} indicates the maximum tonnage each kind of ship can carry. This includes supplies such as fresh water and rations as well as treasure, but not the weight of any weaponry.

entries.name: AC
entries: This is the ship's armour class, which functions in the same way as a character's AC.

entries.name: HP
entries: This is the ship's hit points, which functions in the same way as a character's hit points.

entries.name: Damage Threshold
entries: A ship has immunity to all damage unless it takes an amount of damage equal to or greater than its damage threshold, in which case it takes damage as normal. Any damage that fails to meet or exceed the damage threshold is considered superficial and doesn't reduce the ship's hit points.

entries.name: Weapon Slots
entries: This tells you the number of weapons the ship can be outfitted with. See the "Weaponry" section.

entries.name: Ship Statistics
entries: The following table contains the statistics for ships as described above.

entries.name: Weaponry
entries: Most large ships can be outfitted with weaponry. The table below details the various weapons available and includes the statistics needed to attack with the weapon or damage it.

entries.name: Upgrades
entries: The following tables provides potential upgrades for ships.

entries.name: Random Ships & Crew
entries: The following tables should help you create random ships and their crews on the fly. Not all combinations will line up correctly; for example, you're unlikely to encounter a lizardfolk navy. In these instances, you could reroll the result, or pick a suitable one.

entries.name: Merchant
entries: Merchant ships typically belong to a trading company, such as the Scaly Eye Merchant Company. They are commonly captained by wealthy traders who buy and sell wares in major cities. Their crew are often hired mercenaries from factions such as the Zhentarim or Flaming Fists. Most mercenary crews have neutral alignments.

entries.name: Naval
entries: Naval ships are those belonging to an organised force, such as the White Sails Mercenary Company of Mintarn or the Waterdhavian Navy. Naval ships are most often encountered patrolling major sea lanes for pirates. Most naval crews have lawful-good or -evil alignments.

entries.name: Pirate
entries: Pirate ships are those crewed by criminals and cutthroats. They range from organised bands of Zhentarim thugs to bloodthirsty monstrous humanoids in longboats eager for slaughter and plunder. Pirate ships always attack smaller ships they think they can board. Most pirate crews have chaotic-evil or -neutral alignments.

entries.name: Trade
entries: Trade ships are those such as fishers, whalers, and professional treasure hunters. They differ from merchant ships in that they are actually engaged in a craft of some kind, rather than trading one resource for another. Most trade crews have lawful alignments.

entries.name: Ship Crew
entries: Assume any ship you create is fully crewed. This table provides you with inspiration for the crew races, statistics, and potential captains.

rows: Elf {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}, elf {@creature veteran} with 90 hit points
{@creature lizardfolk}, {@creature lizard king|mm|lizardfolk king}/{@creature lizard queen|mm|queen}

entries.name: Ship Weaponry
entries: Roll once on the ship weaponry table for each available weapon slot the ship has.

entries.name: Ship Treasure
entries: Depending on the variety of ship you encounter, their treasure might take different forms. Anything from chests full of coins, stolen artwork, bags of gems and precious metals, trade goods and magic items can be found aboard.

rows: {@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d4|1d4} gp per crew plus 250 gp of treasure items
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus 500 gp of treasure items
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table A}
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table B}
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table C}

entries: Magic items rolled on the treasure table that are consumable or usable are not left in the hold of a ship, unless they are specifically part of the cargo. More commonly, the magic items are used by the captain of the ship, or by important members of the crew. For example, most magic weapons rolled will be in the hands of the captain, whereas an item that improves perception, such as {@item goggles of night|dmg|goggles of the night} or {@item eyes of the eagle} might belong to the lookout.

As well as the treasure rolled on the table, ships always have less valuable items aboard such as rope, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, kegs of weak ale and the like. Ship lookouts often carry {@item spyglass|phb|spyglasses}, which are worth 1,000 gp. If you don't want your players to have such a valuable item, consider making it cracked, dented, or otherwise impaired.

entries.name: Example Ships & Crew
entries: The following examples of ships and their crew can be dropped straight into your Forgotten Realms campaign, or campaigns set in other worlds with a little tinkering.

entries.name: The Breaking Dusk

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Caravel|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Pirate

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 15 human {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Renk Stormgale (NE male half-orc {@creature bandit captain} wielding a {@item scimitar of speed})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 2 {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, 1 {@object ram}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 15d6|1d6} gp per crew

entries: The Breaking Dusk is a notorious pirate ship that plies the waters south of the Nelanther Isles known as The Race. The ship flies the flag of the Black Armada, three red cutlasses on a field of black. Captain Ander Stormgale is a charismatic individual and would prefer his targets to give up their ship 'willingly' than take it from them by force. At a press, he'd accept a duel instead of a full out naval fight, which is likely to end badly for both boats.

If the Breaking Dusk is forced into combat, it attempts to ram the opposing ship, before the crew use {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks} to tether the two vessels together and board. The {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae} are used primarily as harpoons fulfilling the same purpose as the {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks}, but prefer not to use them due to the damage they cause.

entries.name: The Burning Skull

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Bireme|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Pirate

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 20 {@creature minotaur skeleton|mm|minotaur skeletons}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Black Gurruk (NE male minotaur {@creature necromancer|vgm})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 1 {@object ram}, {@object side-shears|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 20d10|1d10} gp per crew

entries: Famed for terrorising merchant ships that ply Asavir's Channel, the stretch of water between the Nelanther Isles and the Tethyrian Peninsula, the Burning Skull is no named because of the enormous, minotaur-skull shaped {@object ram} which is affixed to the bow of the ship. This {@object ram} contains a steel cage which the crew fill with rags soaked in oil and set alight, causing searing flame to burst from its eyes. Black Gurruk is a gaunt, emaciated minotaur who wields a humanoid spine as a staff. His obsessed with necromancy was inspired by a hideous grimoire he found in the ruins of an ancient city that made him shun the living, and embrace the undead.

In combat, the Burning Skull ignites the {@object ram} at the bow of the ship, and uses its action to {@action Dash} toward the closest foe. The strength of the {@creature minotaur skeleton|mm|minotaur skeletons} means the Burning Skull can easily catch most ships, and smash their flaming {@object ram} into their target's side. As well as its normal damage, the ram deals an additional 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage and ignites any flammable objects it hits. Black Gurruk stays on the ship during attacks, but commands his skeletal warriors to board and kidnap as many as they can.

entries.name: The Flaming Legion

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Sailing Ship|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Naval

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 20 human Flaming Fist {@creature guard|mm|guards}, 10 human Flaming Fist {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Emeline Arranwood (LG female Chondathan human {@creature veteran})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 2 {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, {@object side-shears|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 30d10|1d10} gp per crew

entries: Pride of the Flaming Fist mercenary company, the Flaming Legion is renowned for its speed and crew. Captain Arranwood ranks highly in the Flaming Fists, and is currently in the employ of Grand Duke Ulder Ravengard of Baldur's Gate. The Flaming Legion has been patrolling the major sea lanes into and out of Baldur's Gate, ensuring the port stays open and merchant ships can dock without being harassed by pirates.

When the Flaming Legion enters combat, it tries to cut alongside pirate vessels, shearing their oars or tearing into their hull with the {@object side-shears|CallfromtheDeep}. They use the {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae} to launch flaming bolts onto the deck of pirate ships, aiming to ignite their sails or crack their masts. If they're close enough to board, the Flaming Fist veterans use boarding planks to charge over and incapacitate the crew.

entries.name: Khurgorbaeyag's Spleen

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Coaster|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Pirate

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 20 {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}, 1 {@creature nilbog|vgm}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Skrat (NE female {@creature goblin boss} with a {@item +1 whip})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 1 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 21d6|1d6} gp per crew

entries: Cutting through the waves along the Sword Coast, the yellow-and-red striped coaster is well known to those living along the stretch between the Trollbark Forest and Baldur's Gate. The goblin crew are crazed followers of their slaver god Khurgorbaeyag, who demands that they take hostage as many humanoids as possible to either ransom back to their homes, or sacrifice as offerings to him. Captain Skrat is the worst fanatic of the lot, going into fits of drepression if they fail to take captives every few days. Skrat wields a holy yellow-and-red striped whip, blessed by her god, which she uses to vicious effect on any who question her rule.

Khurgorbaeyag's Spleen avoid combat with larger ships at all costs. Its small size means it can easily nip through rocky passages and escape larger {@item caravel|CallfromtheDeep|caravels} or {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep|sailing ships}. However, when the {@item coaster|CallfromtheDeep} discovers ships of similar build; other {@item coaster|CallfromtheDeep|coasters}, {@item cog|CallfromtheDeep|cogs}, or {@item rowboat|CallfromtheDeep|rowboats}, it attacks with zeal. The {@item coaster|CallfromtheDeep} tries to anchor itself to the opposing ship with a harpoon shot from the {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}, which allows them to draw closer and board. They take as many captives as possible.

entries.name: Luskan's Reprieve

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Warship|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Naval

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 60 human {@creature guard|mm|guards}, 20 human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Erhart Kurth (LN male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 4 {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, 1 {@object mangonel}, 1 {@object ram}, 3 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep|scorpios}, {@object side-shears}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 80d6|1d6} gp per crew

entries: Luskan, the City of Sails, is one of the main bases of piracy on the Sword Coast. A dozen or so small port towns along the coast harbour pirates in their rough-and-tumble taverns, but there is no rival to Luskan when it comes to a safe port, repairs, and new crew. Luskan is ruled by Ships, each of which is responsible for different city business, one of which is piracy. However, in order to prevent war between itself and the powerful Lord's Alliance, Ship Kurth of Luskan provides a few warships to patrol the sea lanes, and sink any pirate vessels that aren't under the protection of its own Ship Suljack. Luskan's Reprieve was constructed solely for this purpose. After the Lord's Alliance began putting pressure on Luskan to cease piracy along the Sword Coast, the City of Sails cut a deal to uild three immense warships, each outfitted with a devastating arsenal of weaponry, to deal with pirates plundering along the coast.

When pursuing pirates, Luskan's Reprieve simply unloads its full arsenal against the enemy vessel. The warship has no agenda save to remove pirates from the shipping routes, and Captain Kurth, brother of High Captain Beniago Kurth, is content to scare them off with a few {@object ballista} bolts and {@object mangonel} shots. Only if the pirates seem to have something worth taking, such as a well-made ship, a magic item, or a fine treasure, does Luskan's Reprieve pursue.

entries.name: The Osprey

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Longship|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Pirate

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 50 human {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Leif Helder (N male Illuskan human {@creature gladiator} with a {@item spellguard shield})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: {@object ram}, 1 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 50d6|1d6} gp per crew

entries: Northlanders are famed for their dragonships, {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships} with figureheads carved to resemble dragons, ocean monsters and other sea life. The Osprey is one of these boats, crewed by a band of Norl raiders from the island of Tuern. The aim of Captain Helder is simple, raid until they've gathered enough supplies to last the vicious winter of their home. Norls lead a life defined by seasons. In the spring and summer they farm, in the autumn they raid, in the winter they hibernate. The Sword Coast is the main target of these raids, small villages are plundered by the Northlanders who take their stored grain, farming tools, and treasures. The Osprey has found their own site in the Moonshae Isles, where Rault the Wise, king of Norland, gives them a safe harbour in return for a cut of their plunder.

The Osprey is built for speed. It has little interest in ship on ship combat, but if pressed will attempt to {@object ram} and board using planks of wood. The crew of the Osprey are burly Northmen who are no strangers to killing, but would rather see their home shores again. Because of this, they fight defensively, aiming to kill captains and break the morale of their foes. When attacking coastal settlements, the longship grounds itself on the closest beach, and the crew unload, headed straight for the village. Again, the Norls will kill if they have to, but would prefer to get in and out as fast as possible, without incurring any casualties.

entries.name: Rusty Harpoon

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Sailing Ship|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Trade

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 20 human {@creature thug|mm|thugs}, 2 {@creature half-ogre (ogrillon)|mm|half-ogres}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Lagertha Scarsson (N female Illuskan human {@creature thug})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 1 {@object ballista}, 2 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep|scorpios}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: None

entries: Hailing from Ruathym, an island populated by Norls north of the Moonshae Isles, the Rusty Harpoon is a beat-up old sailing vessel with a hull plated in a sheet of battered iron. Captain Scarsson is just was weather-beaten as her ship, having spent decades out at sea whaling. She's full of tales of beasts of the deep, bloodthirsty pirates, and 'the one that got away.' The ship reeks of ambergris and fishguts.

The Rusty Harpoon avoids combat at all costs. They're not equipped to fight against pirates, although Captain Scarsson has held her own against them in the past. If pressed, the vessel uses its harpoons to try and blast holes into the opposing ship's hull, hoping to slow it down enough to make a getaway.

entries.name: Siren's Trove

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Cog|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Merchant

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 4 dwarf {@creature guard|mm|guards} and six dwarf {@creature commoner|mm|commoners}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Finellen Goldblood (NG female shield dwarf {@creature noble})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 1 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 10d6|1d6} gp per crew plus 250 gp of precious metal ingots

entries: Siren's Trove is one of the many merchant vessels that sails under the pennant of the Scaly Eye Merchant Company. The proprietor of the Scaly Eye is Lhammauntosz, also known as Mother Claws, an ancient bronze dragon who lairs on the island of Orlumbor. Most pirates aren't foolhardy enough to attack a Scaly Eye ship, for fear of the dragon's wrath, but with the Black Armada gaining power, who knows whether the dragon will be enough of a deterrent.

Captain Goldblood runs a tight ship. She transports goods up and down the Sword Coast, mostly between Fireshear and Ironmaster to the larger cities of Waterdeep and Baldur's Gate. This cargo normally consists of shipments of precious metals or weaponry for militias in the larger cities. Sometimes a private shipment of gems, dwarven sculpture, or magic items is aboard too.

The small cog only has a single {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep} to protect itself against pirates, but a well-placed shot in the captain's chest solves most problems. Thankfully, the ship is under the protection of Mother Claws, who uses scrying to keep a close eye on her ships. If the Siren's Trove is in trouble, there's a good chance the {@creature ancient bronze dragon} will appear to rescue it from whoever was foolhardy enough to attack it.

entries.name: Stormchaser

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Caravel|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Naval

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 15 {@creature priest|mm|priests} of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Stormlord Arden (LE male Chondathan human {@creature war priest|vgm} of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag} with a {@item javelin of lightning})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 2 {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae}, 1 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 15d6|1d6} gp per crew

entries: The Stormchaser is a close to a floating temple as you can imagine. The great wooden vessel is constructed for the sole purpose of getting as close to storms as possible. Here, in the heart of the tempest, the priests of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag} can commune with their god, gaining insight into the future, how best to destroy their foes, and where the greatest storms will appear for their next sermon. Despite this seemingly foolhardy quest, the Stormchaser has not yet been harmed by a squall, perhaps because the clergy aboard are truly devout.

As well as chasing storms, the caravel plays a lesser role as protector and extorter. The ship is well known along the Sword Coast as a pirate-killer, but Stormlord Arden does this for profit, not for good. If the Stormchaser comes across a pirate vessel, it uses its {@object ballista|dmg|ballistae} to fire swinging chain bolts, which are perfect for shattering masts and tearing sails. Once the pirates are immobilised, the priests call down bolts of lightning to strike the vessel, sinking it to the depths. If the Stormchaser spots other, civilised vessels, it pulls up dangerously close and asks for protection payment. Without the Stormchaser, Stormlord Arden claims, their ships would be raided by pirates and wrecked by storms. A few hundred gold pieces is a fair price.

entries.name: Water's Crown

items.name: Type
items.entry: {@item Keelboat|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Function
items.entry: Merchant

items.name: Crew
items.entry: 4 Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards}

items.name: Captain
items.entry: Rabi Bakran (LE female Calishite human {@creature swashbuckler|vgm} with a pet {@creature flying snake})

items.name: Weaponry
items.entry: 1 {@object cannon}, 1 {@object scorpio|CallfromtheDeep}

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: {@dice 4d6|1d6} gp per crew plus 500 gp in stolen goods

entries: Captain Bakran is one of the Black Network's finest fences. She seems to have contacts up and down the Sword Coast, in the Merchant's Domain of Amn and, of course, in her native Calimshan. Rabi has even visited the far flung continent of Chult, and the dotted islands in between. It was on the isle of Lantan that the gnomish worshippers of {@deity Gond|Faerûnian|scag} outfitted Water's Crown with her cannon, a fiersome tube of iron fashioned in the shape of a dragon's head, that spits great balls of metal in a burst of fire and smoke.

Water's Crown avoids trouble wherever possible. Bribes are it's primary source of escaping combat and detection, but if that doesn't work, the {@object cannon} tends to do the job. Captain Bakran's goal is to get in and out of her pick-up as fast as possible, and into some far away port with haste so she can shift the goods before they're even been reported missing.

entries.name: Ship Maps
entries: You may use the following maps in your private games, or in published products provided you credit the cartographer: JVC Parry - {@link jvcparry.com}

entries.name: Tentrix's Cipher
entries: The characters can discover a copy of {@language Tentrix's Cipher|CallfromtheDeep|Sea King Tentrix's cipher} any time during the adventure that you deem appropriate. It is in no way essential to the plot, and the characters might enjoy trying to work it out for themselves without the help of the cipher. If you want to give characters a hint, consider giving them a few of the letters, rather than the entire cipher.

data.name: Appendix F: Character Options
entries: The following options provide players with new character options; four new races and eleven new feats, all of which have a nautical theme, and can be used in the {@i Call from the Deep} campaign.

entries.name: Character Races
entries: The following character races supplement that options in the {@filter Player's Handbook|races|source=phb} and are rarer in the worlds of D&D than the races in that book are. If you're a player, consult with you DM before using any of the races presented here. While they fit perfectly into a nautical campaign such as {@i Call from the Deep}, your DM might want to consider the implications for their world before adding a new race.

items: {@race Merfolk|CallfromtheDeep}
{@race Sahuagin (Malenti)|CallfromtheDeep}
{@race Sahuagin (Sea Devil)|CallfromtheDeep}
{@race Sea Spawn|CallfromtheDeep}
{@race Aldani|CallfromtheDeep}

entries.name: Character Feats
entries: The following feats are designed for play in a nautical campaign, and offer benefits related to life aboard ships, on the coast, or under the waves. At certain levels, your class gives you the Ability Score Improvement feature. Using the {@variantrule feats|phb|optional feats rule}, you can forgo taking that feature to take a {@5etools feat|feats.html} of your choice instead. You can take each feat only once, unless the feat's description says otherwise. You must meet any prerequisite specified in a feat to take that feat. These feats are supplements to those presented in the {@filter Player's Handbook|feats|source=phb}, and you should check with your DM before taking one.

items: {@feat Beast Tamer|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Cannoneer|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Firearms Expert|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Firearms Master|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Navigator|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Net Master|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Sea Legs|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Spear Specialist|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Stoic|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Submariner|CallfromtheDeep}
{@feat Underwater Archer|CallfromtheDeep}

language.name: Tentrix's Cipher
typicalSpeakers: Pirate Lords of the Black Armada
entries: {@note A substitution cipher invented by {@creature Sea King Tentrix|CallfromtheDeep} to obfuscate {@language Common}.}

The characters can discover a copy of Sea King Tentrix's cipher any time during the adventure that you deem appropriate. It is in no way essential to the plot, and the characters might enjoy trying to work it out for themselves without the help of the cipher. If you want to give characters a hint, consider giving them a few of the letters, rather than the entire cipher.

feat.name: Beast Tamer
entries: You have a great ability to communicate with, and command, beasts. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill, if you don't already have it.

If you succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check on a beast, the subject of your check serves you for one hour. The beast can perform simple tasks, such as carry messages, guard doorways, or serve as a mount.

feat.name: Cannoneer
entries: You have spent significant time operating siege equipment, earning you the following benefits:

items: You add your proficiency bonus to attack and damage rolls using siege weapons.
If a siege weapon would require an action to aim, you can use a bonus action instead.
During a short rest, provided you have access to {@item carpenter's tools|phb} or similar equipment, you can restore {@dice 1d10} hit points too a siege weapon.

feat.name: Firearms Expert
entries: Thanks to substantial practice with firearms, you gain the following benefits:

items: You ignore the loading quality of {@filter firearms|items|type=firearm} with which you are proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls.

When you use the {@action Attack} action and attack with a {@filter one-handed weapon|items|type=Melee Weapon|property=!Two-handed}, you can use a bonus action to attack with a loaded {@item pistol} you are holding.

feat.name: Firearms Master
entries: You have practiced extensively with one or more firearms, and mastered the use of smokepowder in these weapons, gaining the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency with the {@item pistol} and {@item musket}.

feat.name: Navigator
entries: You have developed the skills necessary to assist navigation at land and sea. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have proficiency in {@item navigator's tools|phb}. If you are already proficient in {@item navigator's tools|phb}, you can add a bonus equal to your Wisdom modifier to any checks made while using them.
If you can see the stars or sun, you know which way is north.
You can tell which way the weather, including wind and temperature, is going to turn in the next 24 hours.

feat.name: Net Master
entries: Extensive training with {@item net|phb|nets} has earned you the following benefits:

items: You don't suffer disadvantage when attack a creature within 5 feet of you with a net, or when throwing a net up to its long range.
You can add your proficiency bonus to the DC, AC, and damage requirement for escaping or destroying your nets.
When you use the {@action Attack} action and attack with a net, you can use a bonus action to attack with a {@filter one-handed weapon|items|type=Melee Weapon|property=!Two-handed} you are holding.

feat.name: Sea Legs
entries: Your time spent aboard boats has earned you the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in {@filter vehicles (water)|item|type=Vehicle (water)}
You have advantage on saving throws and ability checks made to avoid being knocked {@condition prone}.
Climbing doesn't cost you extra movement.

feat.name: Spear Specialist
entries: You have trained to become a deadly warrior with pole weapons, capable of making lunging attacks and long-distance throws. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you use a {@item javelin|phb}, {@item spear|phb}, or {@item trident|phb}, its damage die changes from a {@dice d6} to a {@dice d8}, and from a {@dice d8} to a {@dice d10} when wielded with two hands, if possible (this feature has no effect if another feature has already improved the weapon's die).
As a bonus action, you can extend the reac of your javelin, spear, or trident by 5 feet.
You can make a ranged attack with a javelin, spear, or trident up to its long range without disadvantage, even underwater.

feat.name: Stoic
entries: You are resilient to fear-incuding effects, and are stoic in the face of horror. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition frightened} or gaining madness effects.

feat.name: Submariner
entries: Your time spent training beneath the waves has earned you the following benefits:

items: You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.
You add your proficiency bonus to the number of minutes for which you can hold your breath.
You add a your proficiency bonus to the number of rounds you can survive after running out of breath.

feat.name: Underwater Archer
entries: You have spent extensive time using ranged weapons under water, and have mastered their trajectories:

items: Your ranged weapon attacks do not automatically mis beyond their normal range underwater.
You don't suffer disadvantage while making ranged weapon attacks within their normal range underwater.

item.name: The Flying Squid
entries: The Flying Squid is a sailing ship powered by a {@creature water elemental} which is bound to a gyroscopic adamantine prison in the hold. Successfully binding the elemental requires a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check.

item.name: Aslaug Waveborn's Spear
entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

entries.name: Waterborne
entries: This item floats on water and other liquids. Its bearer has advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to swim.

item.name: Baragsh's +3 Adamantine Glaive
entries: A {@item +3 adamantine glaive} whose green blade is banded and mottled in a pattern reminiscent of astral skies. It belonged to Baragsh—a male orc captain of a spacefaring vessel from the Astral Plane. A creature attuned to the weapon gains proficiency in vehicles (air), and can add their proficiency bonus to checks made to navigate in the Astral Plane.

entries.name: +3 Adamantine Glaive
entries: You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Whenever you hit an object with this weapon, the hit is a critical hit.

item.name: Captain Tharhava Shestendeliath's Scimitar of Speed
entries: A {@item scimitar of speed} that belonged to Captain Tharhava Shestendeliath—a non-binary blue dragonborn swashbuckler. A creature attuned to the weapon becomes obsessively driven by the draconian voice in their mind commanding them to avenge their death at the hands of Tharcereli. The creature cannot unattune to the weapon, and are unwillig to part with it until Tharcereli is killed. In addition, they gain the breath weapon of a blue {@race dragonborn} (see chapter 2 of the {@i Player's Handbook}).

entries.name: Scimitar of Speed
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, you can make one attack with it as a bonus action on each of your turns.

item.name: Tallyn Amberheart's Flame Tongue Longsword
entries: A {@item flame tongue longsword} which belonged to a Tallyn Amberheart—a human paladin of The Red Knight. Those who wield it hear a commanding woman's voice in their mind instructing during combat. Once per long rest, a creature attuned to the blade can use a bonus action to cause an ally within 30 feet of them that can hear them to use their reaction to make a melee weapon attack.

You can use a bonus action to speak this magic sword's command word, causing flames to erupt from the blade. These flames shed bright light in a 40-foot radius and dim light for an additional 40 feet. While the sword is ablaze, it deals an extra {@damage 2d6} fire damage to any target it hits. The flames last until you use a bonus action to speak the command word again or until you drop or sheathe the sword.

item.name: Werydd Giantsbane's Giant Slayer Greataxe
entries: A {@item giant slayer greataxe} which belonged to Werydd Giantsbane—a shield dwarf champion. A creature attuned to the weapon grows ginger braids and swells in girth. They also gain advantage on saving throws against poison, and resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Giant Slayer
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

When you hit a giant with it, the giant takes an extra {@damage 2d6} slashing damage and must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. For the purpose of this weapon, "giant" refers to any {@filter creature with the giant type|bestiary|type=giant}, including ettins and trolls.

item.name: Crystal Skull
entries: The skull can be used to cast the {@spell speak with dead} spell once per day.

item.name: Drow Slippers of Spider Climbing
entries: While you wear these light shoes, you can move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings, while leaving your hands free. You have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed. However, the slippers don't allow you to move this way on a slippery surface, such as one covered by ice or oil.
This item loses its enchantment permanently if it is exposed to sunlight for 1 hour or longer.

item.name: Delver's Armour
entries: You have a +1 bonus to AC while wearing this armour. While wearing the armour underwater, you can speak {@homebrew its|it's} command word as an action to create a bubble of air around your head. It allows you to breathe normally underwater. This bubble stays with you until you speak the command word again, you doff the armour, or you are no longer underwater

item.name: Figurine of Wondrous Power, Aquamarine Dolphin
entries: A figurine of wondrous power is a statuette of a beast small enough to fit in a pocket. If you use an action to speak the command word and throw the figurine to a point on the ground within 60 feet of you, the figurine becomes a living creature. If the space where the creature would appear is occupied by other creatures or objects, or if there isn't enough space for the creature, the figurine doesn't become a creature.
The creature is friendly to you and your companions. It understands your languages and obeys your spoken commands. If you issue no commands, the creature defends itself but takes no other actions.

The creature exists for a duration specific to each figurine. At the end of the duration, the creature reverts to its figurine form. It reverts to a figurine early if it drops to 0 hit points or if you use an action to speak the command word again while touching it. When the creature becomes a figurine again, its property can't be used again until a certain amount of time has passed, as specified in the figurine's description.
{@creature dolphin|vgm|Aquamarine Dolphin}.
The aquamarine dolphin can become a {@creature dolphin|vgm} for up to 6 hours. While in dolphin form, the figurine allows you to cast the {@spell water breathing} spell at will.

item.name: Marid Conch
entries: This iridescent pink conch shell weighs 1 pound. When you use an action to rub the conch, a cloud of thick sea mist flows out of the shell. At the end of your turn, the mist disappears with a flash of harmless lightning, and a {@creature marid} appears in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.
The first time the shell is rubbed, the DM rolls ot determine what happens.

rows: The {@creature marid} attacks you. After fighting for 5 rounds, the {@creature marid} disappears, and the conch loses its magic.

The {@creature marid} serves you for 1 hour, doing as you command. The marid then returns to the conch. The conch can't be activated again for 24 hours. The next two times the conch is used, the same effect occurs. If the conch is opened a fourth time, the {@creature marid} escapes and disappears, and the conch loses its magic.
The {@creature marid} can cast the {@spell wish} spell three times for you. It disappears when it grants the wish or after 1 hour, and the conch loses its magic.

item.name: Psionic Suit
entries: This item appears to be a Large suit of {@item plate armor|phb|plate armour} weighing 250 lbs. The suit has a hatch at the rear, through which one creature can enter using an action. That creature becomes the pilot.
The psionic suit is a Large object with the following statistics:

items.name: Speed:
items.entry: fly 3 × the pilot's Intelligence score

items.name: Damage Immunities:
items.entry: poison, psychic

entries: Once inside the pilot can operate the suit through thought. The suit has two {@action Attack} options, both of which require an action:

items: Make two gauntlet attacks, with a bonus to the attack roll equal to the pilot's Intelligence score, dealing 11 ({@damage 2d10}) plus the pilot's Intelligence score bludgeoning damage on a hit. The suit can forego the damage to grapple a target (escape DC equals 10 plus the creature's Intelligence score).

Attempt to explode a creature's brain. One creature the pilot can see within 60 feet of it must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw. The DC equals 10 + the pilot's Intelligence modifier. The target takes 27 ({@damage 5d10}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful save.

entries: Any ability check or saving throw made by the suit has a bonus equal to the pilot's Intelligence score, plus their proficiency bonus if applicable.
A pilot with spellcasting (psionics) adds their proficiency to any {@dice d20} roll made by the suit, and can cast their spells through the suit.

entries.by: script stolen by 'Fast Hands' Harrigan from an outpost on the Astral Plane

item.name: Staff of the Eel
item.reqAttune: by a cleric, druid, or warlock
entries: You can use an action to speak this staff's command word and throw the staff on the ground within 10 feet of you. The staff becomes a {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} under your control and acts on its own initiative count. By using a bonus action to speak the command word again, you return the staff to its normal form in a space formerly occupied by the eel.

On your turn, you can mentally command the eel if it is within 60 feet of you and you aren't incapacitated. You decide what action the eel takes and where it moves during its next turn, or you can issue it a general command, such as to attack your enemies or guard a location.

If the eel is reduced to 0 hit points, it dies and reverts to its staff form. The staff then shatters and is destroyed. If the eel reverts to staff form before losing all its hit points, it regains all of them.

item.name: Tome of the Deep
entries: You have resistance to cold damage while attuned to this tome, you can breathe underwater, and you have a swimming speed of 30 feet.

The tome has 10 charges, While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast one of the following spells from it, using your spell save DC: {@spell control water} (4 charges), {@spell create or destroy water} (1 charge), {@spell maelstrom|xge} (5 charges), {@spell tidal wave|xge} (3 charges), {@spell wall of water|xge} (3 charges), {@spell water breathing} (3 charges), {@spell water walk} (3 charges), {@spell watery sphere|xge} (4 charges), {@spell tsunami} (8 charges).
The tome regains {@dice 1d6 + 4} charges daily at dawn. If you expend the last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the tome turns to water, pours through your fingers, and is destroyed

item.name: Wand of Diminution
entries: This wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the reduce effect of the {@spell enlarge/reduce} spell (DC 15) from it.
The wand regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

item.name: Wand of Stone Shape
entries: This wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend one of its charges to cast the {@spell stone shape} spell from it.
The wand regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

item.name: Mind Carapace Breastplate
entries: Any nonmagical suit of heavy armour can be turned by mind flayers into mind carapace armour. Only one creature can attune to it: either a specific mind flayer or one of its thralls. While worn by any other creature, the mind carapace armour functions as normal armour of its kind. To its intended wearer, the armour grants advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws and makes its wearer immune to the {@condition frightened} condition.

item.name: Crest
entries: This {@item +1 dagger} belongs to {@creature Ramazith Flamesinger|CallfromtheDeep}, and has the following additional magic properties:

items: As a bonus action, you can cause a green stone set into the dagger's pommel to shed bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet, or make the stone go dark.
Whenever you starts your turn underwater with 0 hit points, the dagger causes you to rise 60 feet toward the surface.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the spy can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The spy deals an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the spy that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the spy doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spy makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

monster.name: Captain Bartholomew Blackdagger
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The revenant regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the revenant takes fire or radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the revenant's next turn. The revenant's body is destroyed only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: When the revenant's body is destroyed, its soul lingers. After 24 hours, the soul inhabits and animates another humanoid corpse on the same plane of existence and regains all its hit points. While the soul is bodiless, a {@spell wish} spell can be used to force the soul to go to the afterlife and not return.

trait.name: Turn Immunity
entries: The revenant is immune to effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Vengeful Tracker
entries: The revenant knows the distance to and direction of any creature against which it seeks revenge, even if the creature and the revenant are on different planes of existence. If the creature being tracked by the revenant dies, the revenant knows.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The revenant makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature against which the revenant has sworn vengeance, the target takes an extra 14 ({@damage 4d6}) bludgeoning damage. Instead of dealing damage, the revenant can grapple the target (escape {@dc 14}) provided the target is Large or smaller.

action.name: Vengeful Glare
entries: The revenant targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it and against which it has sworn vengeance. The target must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target is {@condition paralyzed} until the revenant deals damage to it, or until the end of the revenant's next turn. When the paralysis ends, the target is {@condition frightened} of the revenant for 1 minute. The {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if it can see the revenant, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The aboleth can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Mucous Cloud
entries: While underwater, the aboleth is surrounded by transformative mucus. A creature that touches the aboleth or that hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature is diseased for {@dice 1d4} hours. The diseased creature can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Probing Telepathy
entries: If a creature communicates telepathically with the aboleth, the aboleth learns the creature's greatest desires if the aboleth can see the creature.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The aboleth makes three tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become diseased. The disease has no effect for 1 minute and can be removed by any magic that cures disease. After 1 minute, the diseased creature's skin becomes translucent and slimy, the creature can't regain hit points unless it is underwater, and the disease can be removed only by heal or another disease-curing spell of 6th level or higher. When the creature is outside a body of water, it takes 6 ({@damage 1d12}) acid damage every 10 minutes unless moisture is applied to the skin before 10 minutes have passed.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Enslave (3/Day)
entries: The aboleth targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed} by the aboleth until the aboleth dies or until it is on a different plane of existence from the target. The {@condition charmed} target is under the aboleth's control and can't take reactions, and the aboleth and the target can communicate telepathically with each other over any distance.

Whenever the {@condition charmed} target takes damage, the target can repeat the saving throw. On a success, the effect ends. No more than once every 24 hours, the target can also repeat the saving throw when it is at least 1 mile away from the aboleth.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The aboleth makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Swipe
entries: The aboleth makes one tail attack.

legendary.name: Psychic Drain (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: One creature {@condition charmed} by the aboleth takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage, and the aboleth regains hit points equal to the damage the creature takes.

Residing in the lower vaults is the aboleth Kzixxaro. This creature hails from the Far Realm. It made its way to the Material Plane with the Abolethic Sovereignty. Their aim is to open a gateway to the Far Realm, allowing their unimaginable ancestors into the Material Plane. In the short term, this involves corrupting important citizens of Neverwinter to access greater magic.

In the past few decades the Sovereignty has been in decline. Conflicts with other societies have forced the leaders into the Underdark where they are better able to defend themselves. Kzixxaro remains in Neverwinter to continue to observe the city. Kzixxaro several agents within Neverwinter, including Brother Atlavast and Mayor Soman Galt. These two were manipulated by Kzixxaro promising them their desires, and using {@spell phantasmal force} to mimic them when they return with information.

Unfortunately for Kzixxaro, it's powerful telepathic influence in Neverwinter has not gone unnoticed. When Zellix'Phor merged with Slarkrethel, the elder brain realised the potential threat Kzixxaro could pose should it gain sway over Neverwinter and return the Sovereignty to its former power. Because of this, Kraken Society agents were told to pay Garrundar the Vile ({@adventure N12. Pirates' Skyhold|CallfromtheDeep|5|N12. Pirate's Skyhold}) for his undead pirate mercenaries. They aim to attack the House of Knowledge and kill Kzixxaro, thus eliminating a potential enemy of the Colony of Zellix'Phor.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The noble adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the noble must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The priest's spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The priest can breathe air and water.

action.name: Thunderous Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d10}) thunder damage.

action.name: Voice of the Kraken (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A kraken speaks through the priest with a thunderous voice audible within 300 feet. Creatures of the priest's choice that can hear the kraken's words (which are spoken in Abyssal, Infernal, or Primordial) must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The necromancer is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). The necromancer has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Grim Harvest (1/Turn)
entries: When necromancer kills a creature that is neither a construct nor undead with a spell of 1st level or higher, the necromancer regains hit points equal to twice the spell's level, or three times if it is a necromancy spell.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The merfolk can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Mercantile Culture
entries: The merfolk has a +3 bonus to checks made to bargain and communicate with merchants and traders.

trait.name: Underwater Weapons Training
entries: Ranged attacks the merfolk makes with {@item spear|phb|spears}, {@item javelin|phb|javelins}, and {@item trident|phb|tridents} don't automatically miss a target beyond their normal range while underwater.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The gladiator has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the gladiator hits with it (included in the attack).

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The merfolk can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Mercantile Culture
entries: The merfolk has a +3 bonus to checks made to bargain and communicate with merchants and traders.

trait.name: Underwater Weapons Training
entries: Ranged attacks the merfolk makes with {@item spear|phb|spears}, {@item javelin|phb|javelins}, and {@item trident|phb|tridents} don't automatically miss a target beyond their normal range while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gladiator makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, or 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The gladiator adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the gladiator must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

monster.name: Combat Training Construct

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands Deep Speech and Undercommon but can't speak

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The helmed horror has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Spell Immunity
entries: The helmed horror is immune the following spells: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell lightning bolt}.

trait.name: Shove
entries: The helmed horror can {@action shove} a creature within 5 feet of it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The helmed horror makes two longsword attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage if used with two hands.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The merrow can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The merrow makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). The merrow has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Otanyn's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 10}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Otanyn can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Emissary of the Sea
entries: Otanyn can communicate simple ideas with beasts that can breathe water. They can understand the meaning of her words, though she has no special ability to understand them in return.

trait.name: Guardians of the Depths
entries: Otanyn ignores any of the drawbacks caused by a deep, underwater environment.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Otanyn makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Vlaryn's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 10}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Vlaryn can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Emissary of the Sea
entries: Vlaryn can communicate simple ideas with beasts that can breathe water. They can understand the meaning of her words, though she has no special ability to understand them in return.

trait.name: Guardians of the Depths
entries: Vlaryn ignores any of the drawbacks caused by a deep, underwater environment.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Vlaryn makes two melee weapon attacks. If Vlaryn takes the Attack action and attacks with a melee weapon she is holding in one hand, she can also make an attack with a different light melee weapon that she's holding in her other hand.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 bludgeoning damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The conjurer is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). The conjurer has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The merfolk can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Mercantile Culture
entries: The merfolk has a +3 bonus to checks made to bargain and communicate with merchants and traders.

trait.name: Underwater Weapons Training
entries: Ranged attacks the merfolk makes with {@item spear|phb|spears}, {@item javelin|phb|javelins}, and {@item trident|phb|tridents} don't automatically miss a target beyond their normal range while underwater.

trait.name: Benign Transportation (Recharges after the Conjurer Casts a Conjuration Spell of 1st Level or Higher)
entries: As a bonus action, the conjurer teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that it can see. If it instead chooses a space within range that is occupied by a willing Small or Medium creature, they both teleport, swapping places.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

monster.name: Shava the Damned

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

languages: the languages it knew in life

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deathlock's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deathlock is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It regains its expended spell slots when it finishes a short or long rest. It knows the following warlock spells:

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Shava wields a {@item +3 rod of the pact keeper}, and wears a {@item ring of evasion} and a {@item ring of swimming} (included in her statistics).

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The deathlock has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

action.name: Deathly Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) necrotic damage).

action.name: Grave Bolts
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 9} to hit, range 120 ft., one or two targets. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage. If the target is Large or smaller, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or become {@condition restrained} as shadowy tendrils wrap around it for 1 minute. A {@condition restrained} target can use its action to repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Ring of Evasion (3/Day)
entries: When Shava fails a Dexterity saving throw, she can use her reaction to succeed on that saving throw instead.

trait.name: Injured
entries: The githyanki initially has 30 hit points remaining.

trait.name: Stolen Body
entries: The githyanki's brain has been replaced by an {@creature intellect devourer}, which controls the githyanki and has total cover against attacks and other effects originating outside the githyanki. The intellect devourer knows everything its host knew.

If the host body dies, the intellect devourer must leave it. A {@spell protection from evil and good} spell cast on the body drives the intellect devourer out. The intellect devourer is also forced out if the githyanki regains its devoured brain by means of a {@spell wish}. By spending 5 feet of its movement, the intellect devourer can voluntarily leave the body, teleporting to the nearest unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. The body then dies, unless its brain is restored within 1 round.

trait.name: Detect Sentience
entries: The intellect devourer inside the githyanki can sense the presence and location of any creature within 300 feet of it that has an Intelligence of 3 or higher, regardless of interposing barriers, unless the creature is protected by a {@spell mind blank} spell.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

action.name: Silver Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage. This is a magic weapon attack. On a critical hit against a target in an astral body (as with the {@spell astral projection} spell), the githyanki can cut the silvery cord that tethers the target to its material body, instead of dealing damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The sea lion can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The sea lion has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The sea lion has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the sea lion's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Swimming Leap
entries: With a 10-foot swimming start, the sea lion can long jump out of or across the water up to 25 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Gnome Cunning
entries: Oda has advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic.

action.name: Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Lightfooted
entries: The swashbuckler can take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Suave Defense
entries: While the swashbuckler is wearing light or no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Charisma modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swashbuckler makes three attacks: one with a dagger and two with its rapier.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the berserker can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The troll has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The scrag can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it is fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The troll makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

variant.name: Loathsome Limbs
entries: Whenever the troll takes at least 15 slashing damage at one time, roll a {@dice d20} to determine what else happens to it:

items.name: 1–10:
items.entry: Nothing else happens.

items.name: 11–14:
items.entry: One leg is severed from the troll if it has any legs left.

items.name: 15–18:
items.entry: One arm is severed from the troll if it has any arms left.

items.name: 19–20:
items.entry: The troll is decapitated, but the troll dies only if it can't regenerate. If it dies, so does the severed head.

entries: If the troll finishes a short or long rest without reattaching a severed limb or head, the part regrows. At that point, the severed part dies. Until then, a severed part acts on the troll's initiative and has its own action and movement. A severed part has AC 13, 10 hit points, and the troll's Regeneration trait.
A severed leg is unable to attack and has a speed of 5 feet.

A severed arm has a speed of 5 feet and can make one claw attack on its turn, with disadvantage on the attack roll unless the troll can see the arm and its target. Each time the troll loses an arm, it loses a claw attack.

If its head is severed, the troll loses its bite attack and its body is {@condition blinded} unless the head can see it. The severed head has a speed of 0 feet and the troll's Keen Smell trait. It can make a bite attack but only against a target in its space.

The troll's speed is halved if it's missing a leg. If it loses both legs, it falls {@condition prone}. If it has both arms, it can crawl. With only one arm, it can still crawl, but its speed is halved. With no arms or legs, its speed is 0, and it can't benefit from bonuses to speed.

action.name: Anchor Hand
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

First mate of Captain Callous, Anka is a simple ogre pirate who loves life on the High Seas. Although she's somewhat dim-witted, Anka has a good natural sense of direction and is a dedicated crewmember of the Devil's Fin. Anka's most curious feature is her missing arm, which has been replaced with an enormous ship's anchor.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Inertial Armour
entries: The golem is considered to be under the effect of a {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour} spell. A {@spell dispel magic} spell can remove this effect until the golem's next Short Rest.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Mind Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem magically emits psychic energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Callous' spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Firearm Expert
entries: Callous has had extensive practice with firearms, giving him the following benefits:

items: He ignores the loading quality of firearms with which he is proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on his ranged attack rolls.
If he makes an attack with a one-handed weapon, he can use a bonus action to attack with a loaded firearm he is holding.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Callous wears {@item gloves of swimming and climbing}. While wearing them, climbing and swimming don't cost him extra movement, and he has a +5 bonus to Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks made to climb or swim.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Pistol
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Callous adds 2 to his AC against one melee attack that would hit him. To do so, Callous must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Captain Callous is a notorious tiefling pirate captain of The Devil's Fin. He is a direct descendant of {@deity Asmodeus|Faerûnian|scag} himself and is one of the most-feared pirates in the Sea of Swords.
Captain Callous has five potential stat blocks, one for each chapter in which the characters might encounter him.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I will become the most feared pirate alive.

entries.name: Bond
entries: The Devil's Fin is my life and was a gift from {@deity Asmodeus|Faerûnian|scag}. To lose it would be to lose my link to him.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I always believe I can escape.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: The coelenite has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects that target only it.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The coelenite can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if the coelenite has half of its hit points or fewer. A target hit by the attack is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). The coelenite has two claws, each of which can grapple one target.

A coelenite (pronounced {@i SEE-len-ite}) is a roughly humanoid coral-like creature made of hundreds of thousands of tiny organisms no larger than a pebble. The tiny creatures that make up a coelenite are brightly coloured and amorphous, but when they group together in a colony they harden like coral and take on a more structured form. These bodies have crushing claws akin to those of a giant crab and almost impenetrable armour. In addition, their colonial nature makes them resistant a wide variety of spells and conditions.

entries.name: Water Dependant
entries: Despite their tough exoskeleton, the interior of a coelenite colony is amorphous and mushy. This interior requires a near constant supply of water to remain hydrated. Many sailors claim that the easiest way to kill a coelenite is to lure it inside a cabin and lock it in overnight.

entries.name: Mass Minds
entries: Should enough coelenites come together, they can produce an intelligence above that of a regular colony. These mass minds are capable of commanding other coelenite colonies and even manifesting magical effects. Luckily, if enough of the organisms that form the mass mind are killed, it loses these cognitive qualities.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: The coelenite has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects that target only it.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: If the coelenite has half its hit points or fewer its Intelligence score drops to 5 (-3), it can't use its Innate Spellcasting, Limited Telepathy, or Psychic Crush.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The coelenite can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: The coelenite can magically tarnsmit simple messages and images to any creature within 60 feet of it that can understand a language. This form of telepathy doesn't allow the receiving creature to telepathically respond unless that creature is a coelenite.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The coelenite's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if the coelenite has half of its hit points or fewer. A target hit by the attack is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). The coelenite has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Psychic Crush {@recharge 5}
entries: The coelenite targets one creature that it can sense within 60 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A coelenite (pronounced {@i SEE-len-ite}) is a roughly humanoid coral-like creature made of hundreds of thousands of tiny organisms no larger than a pebble. The tiny creatures that make up a coelenite are brightly coloured and amorphous, but when they group together in a colony they harden like coral and take on a more structured form. These bodies have crushing claws akin to those of a giant crab and almost impenetrable armour. In addition, their colonial nature makes them resistant a wide variety of spells and conditions.

entries.name: Mass Minds
